div.head: TO THE HONOURABLE Mr. Charles Boyl.
div.p: THERE's no Condition can subsist wholly upon itself: And I am bound to depend, as every Man, more or less, is, upon the Favour of the World, to carry him through the troublesome Iourney of this Life: Nor do I think it my Misfortune to wait upon a Great Man's rising sometimes, to put him in mind of me. While I can keep my self out of the necessity of flattering Fools, I shall not very much repine at my Condition. I'm sure I'm safe here, because you are safe every where: And when a common Consent encourages an Opinion, I shall hardly be thought in the wrong, to do as other People do.

Sir, when Poetry becomes, a Man's Business, 'twill hardly prove another Man's Diversion: Tho' a Play once a Year, looks very like turning into the Profession, I am a little better acquainted with the Town, than to impose my self this way upon 'em; and let it be the defence of my Writing, that I have nothing else to do.

I know Play-Writers, like Men of other Employments, where the Honest Advantages are so small, are suspected in their Dealings, of indirect, underhand Practices, to carry on their Trade. For my part, Sir, I propose nothing more than an opportunity of declaring myself in my turn, that I have grown up by degrees, with the general Understanding, and Iudgment of the Town, into a Respect and Honour that every body has for you: This, Sir, is the only way I have of Publishing mine: and Writing has always been allow'd of, when there was no other way left of discovering the Passion.

Some Convenience, and a great deal of Pleasure, first carry'd me into this wanton way of Wickedness, (those old Seducers, Profit, and Pleasure) that have brought at last a great many of both Sexes, into the common Entertainment of the Town.

I have had my ends of this Play, and shou'd have been glad if it had answer'd every Bodies: I think it has its Beauties, tho' they did not appear upon the Stage, and 'tis not the smallest Commendation, to be able to divert you in private.

If I run into the Course of a Dedication, I shall be lost in the Character of Mr. Boyl; for when I have said all I can, I shall fall short of every Man's Opinion; and no body, but your self, will think I can say enough of you: At home, or abroad; in the Camp, or in the Court, Mr. Boyl's Behaviour, and Address, is the Pattern of every Gallant Man's imitation; so much, that, from what I have seen, and heard of you, I must believe that there is no Province of Humanity, but, at one time or other of your Life, you are design'd to Command. Let it satisfie, Sir, your present Ambition, to Conquer in the fairest Field of Victory, to Triumph in the Court, and in spight of the Cabals, and whispers of the Drawing-Room, to be universally allow'd the fine Gentleman: Which as it seems the easiest, has always been thought the hardest Character of a Great Man to maintain.
Sir, since the distance of your Quality, and Fortune, has made it impossible to come near you, as a Friend, I hope you will allow me to wait upon you as,

closer.signed: Your Real Humble Servant, Tho. Southerne.

div.head: PROLOGUE
div.l: THey who must write (for writings a Disease)
Shou'd make it their whole study how to please:
And that's a thing our Author fain wou'd do;
But wiser Men, than he, must tell him how:
For you're so changeable, that every Moon,
Some upstart whimsie knocks the old ones down.
Sometimes bluff Heroes please by dint of Arms:
And sometimes tender Nonsense has its Charms:
Now Love, and Honour strut in buskin'd Verse:
Then, at one leap, you stumble into Farce.
Like true Fanaticks, never long content
With any setled Form of Government:
Eager in choice, as eager in forsaking;
You first blaspheme the Gods of your own making.
Let Poets henceforth lay their Rules aside;
And take some ruling Planet for their Guide:
No more frequent their fam'd Parnassus's tops;
Unless it be to place their Teliscopes:
For such as hope to merit your esteem,
Must quit their Horace, and erect a Scheme.
Thus they may find a way to please the Pit,
Provided they insure their Plays from Wit.
Our Author, this way doubtless of Success,
(For some Men have no Stars, as Lilly says)
Himself, and Play, upon the Boxes throws,
From perfect Beauty's, to imperfect Beaus.
To you, fair Sirs (for I must call you so,
Since Art, in spight of Nature, makes a Beau)
Who in side Box, in seeming Iudgment sit,
Like Barron-Tell-Clocks to attend the Pit;
In all humility he does submit.
Not that he needs to doubt you for his Play:
We know your Courage lies another way.
Nor will he Court you, like some servile Elves,
Who flatter you as much, as you your selves:
Let them proclaim the Conquest of your looks;
That bug-bear word shall never burn his Books.
You, Ladys, he adores, and owns your Charms,
More powerful, than the greatest Monarchs Arms.
Hopes the kind Heav'ns will all your Wishes grant,
Whether they be for Husband, or Gallant:
Nay, Bath, and Wells, at once, if both you want.
Not doubting your good Nature for a Man,
Who, to oblige you, does the best he can.

div.head: THE Maids last Prayer; OR, ANY, rather than Fail.
SCENE I. Trickitt's House.
div.p: Gayman and Granger, from Play.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: A Pox on your Bassett: Catch me at that damn'd Game, this Twelvemonth agen, and may I live to value my self upon the Modish Reputation of a gentile Tallieur.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: And that has made a Fortune before now.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: It never shall make mine: Death! I have no patience to be eternally jilted by Alpieus.â€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: But not the Ladies, Granger.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: The Ladies? There lies the secret: When you design a Bank, you first consider what Beauties you shall get to draw in Custom: And I cou'd tell you, as a certain Lord did, when askt, why he never play'd at my Lady Pampockett's.â€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: As how, pray?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Why, since you press meâ€” I don't like your Women.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Sure you forget my Charming Lady Trickitt: And that's Inhospitable in her own House.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: No, faith, I have her in my thoughts, a fresh Idea of her, and her little Cheats; her nauseous toss, and all those Affectations, that ought to make a Woman odious to Men of sense.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Gad a mercy, St. George for England!

Now wou'd your Man of Travel and true Dress, be transported, with what your right born Brittain finds such fault with; and think these little agreements of absolute necessity to make a Mistress relish.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: To make a Mistress relish! to make a Mistress stink of the familiarity of half the Town: I must own my want of good breeding; the Hogo's much too strong for me.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Thou Monster of ingratitude! I heard this very Woman, within this Month, say, there was not so agreeable a Man in Town, as Mr. Granger; so generous a Friend; and so good humour'd a Gentleman; especially upon a winning hand.â€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Why there's the Devil on't: One Night, about that time, she lost her Money, and I was lucky: She, to my Face, cry'd up the Generosity of those, who make their Friends partakers of their good Fortune: And I was too well satisfied with mine to contradict her: Next Morning, she sent to speak with me; on earnest Business, which was, to borrow 500 Guinny's; promising to repay me; with such a Grace, that no one, who had not the Honour to know her Ladyship, cou'd have had the Heart to refuse her.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: And how cou'd you retire like a Man of Honour?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I told her, mine was a Younger Brother's Fortune; not to be ventur'd but on good Security; she indeed kindly proffer'd me the best she had about her.â€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: And so you Sign'd, and Seal'd?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: No, faith, without advising with Counsel, I knew 'twas so encumbred with Fops, and Blockheads, there was nothing in remainder for a reasonable Man: There's not a Rogue so nauseous, but is welcome to her for his Mony: All that will be Losers, Lenders, or Givers, have an equal claim to her good Graces: From the grinning stinking Lord, to the fat Booby Squire, whose unsavoury Vapours wou'd offend the Ladies Noses, in any Ruel, but her Ladyship's.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: But what say you, to my lovely Lady Malepert? She's more particular; One Man at once suffices there.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Wou'd it were always to be her Husband.

That a Woman, at Eighteen, an Age, when Love, and Pleasure us'd to rule, shou'd in the midst of Plenty, value her self upon the Reputation of a Publican, and always sit at the RÃ©ceit of Custom! Rot her, she has less mercy than a Mountebank's Bill: No Cure, no Mony, is a moral Honesty in the Surgeon; but no Mony, no Cure, is only the Conscience of a Whore.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Prejudice of Education, Granger: Her Inclinations may be good, and Wishwell's influence over-rule 'em: She governs there, and Interest governs her.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Nay, Mrs. Wishwell's the very Flower of modern Industry, and shews a Master-stroak in all she does: First, to insinuate, at her Age, into the Inclinations of this young Lady; then, with her Character, to perswade the Family, she was a fit instructer for her; and which is more, to make Lord Lofty, tho' turn'd of Fifty, agreeable to almost Fifteen.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: But above all, to break the League 'twixt her, and her Lord's Aunt, my Lady Susan, who tho' a Friend to the Projection, cou'd not endure to have it brought about by any but the Family.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Yes, that Youthful Virgin of five and forty, with a swelling Rump, bow Leggs, a shining Face, and colly'd Eyebrows (of what breath she pleases) sure she's an Original: 'Tis the most familiar Duck, always engag'd a Month before hand: She'd no more miss a Ball, than the curling her little finger, when she eats, tho' she hobbles worse than Abigall in the Scornful Lady, when she has broke her Crupper.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: No matter for all that, I am oblig'd to her.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: O yes, by, having the Honour to be your Bawd, she thought to recommend her self to be my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Despising her, as you do, why are you so often with her? Your visits are as regular as my young Masters to the crooked Heiress, whom his prudent Parent has pickt out, to be the future Blessing of the Family.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Why, to confess my Sins, and blush for all at onceâ€” since I refus'd Trickitt the 500 Pound, I don't know what the Devil's the matter with her, but she has made me some advances, that have put me into a Curiosity of knowing the meaning of 'em. But, Damn her, while I believe her endeavouring to perswade me that she's in Love with me, I think I am in Love with her: I can't see to the end on't: But she, and my worthy Lady Susan, being, as you know, inseparable, I need explain no farther.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Speaking of Trickitt, as you have always done, I durst have sworn of her whole Sex, she was the last in your opinion.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: And so she is.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: And yet you follow her.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I consider the Principles of a Mistress, no more than of a good Companion, they are both the Instruments of pleasure for the time; and to be trusted with nothing beyond that meeting.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: But can you Love without esteem?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Why, you Court Lady Malepert; you can have no real esteem for a Woman of her mercinary Character.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Cou'd I reclaim her, I shou'd be happy: At least the, Tryal will be pleasant.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: How does this agree with your Passion for Maria? Can you be false to her?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: She won't let me be true to her: I have try'd her every way, but one; and that one way, that high way of Matrimony, 'twill come to at last, I believe.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I always thought Wishwell your Friend, in this Business.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: The Lord has got the better of me: yet I will visit her agen, to get her into my Interest, if I can; if I fail in that, I shall at least have the pleasure of railing at her.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Nay, never think of curing the Mercenary Itch in an Old Woman: 'Tis the very Tetter of that Sex: and more or less, breaks out upon 'em all: The young ones are not clear on't.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Here comes the Noble Lord Malepert, and that Minor of Chivalry, Sir Ruff Rancounter: their Conversation shou'd be diverting; let's stand back and observe 'em.

div.stage: Enter Sir Ruff, Lord Malepert hanging upon his Arm.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Granger, methought, us'd your Lordship a little scurvily: I wonder you cou'd bear it; for my part, I always make mince-meat of any Fellow that offers but half so much to me.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Pish, he lost his Money, and I teaz'd him; these things are nothing between us: Besides, I am witty upon him in my turn, I call him Wasp.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Nay, I must allow you are too hard for him at Repartee: but a Man of Honour, my Lord, shou'd never put up the least indignity: You never see him offer the like to Gayman.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Who? Gayman? Lord! he's the servil'st Fellow, the Ministers do so laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Why, he'll fight, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O Jesu! Sir! I never said any thing to the contrary: He's a very worthy Person; I always reckon him among my best Friends, whatever I say of him: I assure you he did all his Exercises at the Academy to a Miracle: He and I rid the great Horse together.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: The great Horse! my Lord? sure you forget your self, your Lady's Padd went a great way with you.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Why really, Sir Ruff, you won't believe me;
But I became the manage so well, that I verily believe I had been in the Army, but for one thingâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: What was that, pray?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Why, they said Riding too much wou'd teach me to turn in my Toes, and spoil my Dancing; and you know a Body wou'd not do that for less than a Regiment; and they offered me but a Troop. Was you at the Play last Night?

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Yes, what of that?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Was Wishwell there? Well, she's the best Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: You have cause to say so.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Yes, really, she's always so particular to me: I have seen her so play upon my Lord Lofty when he was much a greater Man than I.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Has not she play'd for him too, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: This Blockhead will tell him he's a Cuckold to his Face.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Well, my Wife's mightily oblig'd to her:

She's admitted to her Toilett, when she's abroad to Dutchesses: then she gave her the finest Present of Stuffs a Board an East-India Ship, Lofty had but just given it her: I am to have a Gown and Slippers of it my self.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Yes, and a Night-Cap too. Can this Puppy be so blind, not to know who made his Wife that Present?

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: When was you at Mrs. Siam's?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Last Night, at Ten, we raffled there, Lord Lofty, Wishwell, my Wife, and I: My Wife sent me home for more Money; but before I came back, where do you think they were gone?â€” Why, even to Wishwell's, where we had the prettiest Supper: After we rose from Table, Wishwell took me aside, as she us'd to do, to rail with her, at the Vices of the Age; I thank her, she knew which way to oblige meâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: And the whole Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Why, after all, this was no Complement to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Why, Lord, Sir Ruff, you don't think we left her alone: we were better bred, I assure you: my Lord and she went into the little Room, with the Crimson Couch, to talk of State Affairs: Now you must know my Wife understands State Affairs to a Miracle: She picks up all the News of the Drawing-Room, to inform me of at Night; for her whole Business, you must know, is to make me riseâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Out a Bed from her, I believe you.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Wou'd she had a better Employment.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: To make you rise! 'tis lost Labour very often, my Lord; for, after all, you don't look much like a Man of Business.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir! you're mistaken in me; I love State Affairs mightily; and understand 'em, tho' I say it, passably well: Why, I had a Politick Master all the while I was in France; without Vanity I got off a Sheriff, this Winter, in spight of the Commissioners.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Was not Maria with you at Wishwell's?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Maria came in, and interrupted us; Maria came inâ€” a Lady of your Acquaintance,â€” as good a Maid, tho' I say itâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Tho' you say it? what can you say of her?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Why, thou hast such an akeing Tooth after that Maiden-head of hers; but she won't marry you: Besides she has no Maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Has your Lordship no Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Why, what do you mean, Sir Ruff? I never was ask'd such an uncivil Question in all my Life. Jesu! mayn't a Man make a Jest, or so, upon a Friend, in a civil way?

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Not where my Honour, or the Honour of my Mistress, is concern'd.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Pish, I honour her as much as you do: I think her Virtuous, let the World say what they will of her.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Will that repair the Injury? Dammee, I'll have Satisfaction, or I'll wring your Neck off.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Help there, Treason, I am the Lord Malepert, seize him some Bodyâ€” But, dear Sir Ruff, I meant no harm in the World? but as I love railing mightily, I can't forbear a witty Jest sometimesâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.l: Damn your dull Jest:
This Place and Company protect you:
And so Adieu Lord Loggerhead.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Mr. Granger, Mr. Gayman, your Servant: Were you at the Park last Night?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Was your Lordship a Hunting with the King?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.l: Jesu! la Hunting? No, God forbid. You have the prettyest
Trimming, Mr. Granger.
Did you buy it at the French Protestants?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: That's a question for my Taylor?
Who was he that left you just now?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Honest Sir Ruff. Does the Queen see Company?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: He us'd your Honour something coursely, I thought.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Pish, 'tis a Pleasant Blustering Fellow, I allow him all his Humours, and he knows mine.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: It seems he does.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Now you must know I am very quiet, and good natur'd, 'till I am vex'd, but then I'm the Devilâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: At Twelve I'll meet you in the Park.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Stay, stay, we'll go together.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Did you lose to Night, Mr. Granger?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Did your Lady Sup at Mrs. Wishwell's?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Pish, did you win then?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Did my Lord Lofty Sup there too?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Very foolish; were you a Saver then?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Zounds! did you leave 'em alone?
That's the way for you to be a winner.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Well, my Wife does so laugh at him, when we're alone: she's only Civil to him, because he's a Relation: She say's his Conversation's so out of Fashion; and if he shou'd pretend to make Loveâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: She wou'd make very good sport with him.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I dare swear for her.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Yes, I vow now, for I assure you, she has a world of Wit, as my Aunt Susan says: She'll play upon me sometimes before Company; but that you know is the fashionâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: What, to play upon your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Pish, no, I mean to use a Husband negligently in publick; but then she's so fond of me in private: Nay, Faith, out Humours jump to a hair, she'll rail to a Miracle, and you know I love railing mightily. But do you resolve to quit Basset?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Dam it, 'twas invented by the Levellers, and suited to all Capacities; 'tis the Devil and all, to lose always to Fools.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: I always to lose too, but witty Men,
You know, are seldom lucky.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I must to my Lodgings; send some Rouleaus to the Bank, to pay my damn'd Debts, and learn to be wiser for the future: Shall I have your Honour's Company?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Jesu! Mr. Granger, I beg you Ten Thousand Pardons; I covet no Man's Company so much as yours; but I must go to Sir Feminine Fanviles, drink Tea at Siam's, and then to the Levees of three Privy Counsellors.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: You're a necessary Man to 'em.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Why, really, bar Sir Faminine, there's not a Man in Town carries 'em fresher News.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Nay, he's a Prodigy of Intelligence.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: And very well with the Ministry, upon my word:
No matter who's in play, he sticks to the Offices, and not the Men; there's not a word spoken in the Play-House, Chocolate-House, or Drawing-Room, but he gives 'em an account of.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: You forget the Coffee-Houses.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O filthy! he leaves them to such as can endure the stink of Tobacco: No, he's too delicate for that, and I believe nothing less than the betraying the Secrets of a bosom Friend, cou'd perswade him to speak to a Man that came out of one: I went to him from visiting an Old Aunt, that was taking a Pipe:
The Smoak, I believe, got into my Perriwig, but he smelt me out immediately, and made his Valet de Chambre turn me down stairs; I must say that for him:
Nay, I vow he's an extraordinary fine Gentleman,
And knows a Fool, as wellâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: As your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Yes, I vow now, does he: Gad so, 'tis almost Eight a Clock, So dear Mr. Granger, and Mr. Gayman, your Servant;
You'll be at my Aunt Susan's this Afternoon; 'tis her day you know.

sp.speaker: Grang. Gay.
sp.p: Infallibly, my Lord.

div.stage: Exit Ld. Mal. one way, Granger, Gayman, another.
Scene drawn, shows La. Trickitt, Maria, and Garnish, making up the Bank, Cards scatter'd about.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: What luck's this, Child? to win of Sir Limber Lowly, and my Lady Sinker, (both desperate Debts) lose all our ready Money, besides a Sum to Granger.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Did Mr. Granger win? I came in late, you know.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Upon my Life, Child, we owe him a Hundred and Fifty Pound.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I take your word, Madam, but indeed I thought he had been a Loser, I'm sure he fretted at the usual rate.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: You mistake him, Child, 'tis his Humour, he's as hard to please, as a Sick Monkey; and when he is;
It fits as awkardly upon him, at a French Suit on a young Spaniard, newly set out to Travel.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Granger's Man's to wait on your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Tell him I'm gone to Bed, bid him come after Dinner, and the
Money shall be readyâ€”
He's strangely pressing; methinks
He might have stay'd 'till next Bassetâ€”
Now if this Fellow be Fool enough not to understand me, and shou'd bring in the Money, all will be discover'd.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam, he says, Mr. Granger
Gives his Service to your Ladyship, and has sent
You the Hundred and Fifty Pounds he lost to the Bank.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Well, this sitting up does so prey upon the memory:
Why, I durst ha' sworn we ow'd him that Sum:
Well, Child, as't happens, this is no ill Night to thee.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Thanks to the timely Messageâ€”

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: They come so seldom, but Mr. Granger's the most punctual Man.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: He's every way a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: So Waspish, there's no living with him:
Of all things, he's my aversion.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: I must be better satisfy'd of that, before I believe you.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: He's sometimes Splenetick indeed, but 'tis thro' so much good Sense, and Breeding, 'tis rarely seen, and always diverting.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Dear Maria, how can you say this? Did you ever know him Offer at a Civil thing? No, 'tis an arrant Churl:
And for the Honour you mention, Mr. Garnish,
He talks too much of it, to have more than his share.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I'll not dispute his Character with you:
Shall we meet anon at my Lady Susans?

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: I'll not fail you, Child, she's one of the Gang.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I take my leave.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Adieu Maria, adieu dear Childâ€”
Why what a Credulous Creature this is!

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Lord, Madam, how can you impose so upon your Friend?

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Tell me of Friendship, no, as my Lord says
There's no true Friend, but Monyâ€”

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: How, Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: And your self. But let us get as much Money as we can; 'twill secure your Friendship to me.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: It cannot need such a securityâ€” Well, Madam, You have reconcil'd me to some thingsâ€” for your Service.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: And for your own, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: That I cou'd never have thought on, for my self.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: And you have perswaded me to another thingâ€”

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: For both our Services.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: That I wou'd ha' done for no body else.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: There's no repenting of any thing I can do, for you,
Or with you; I am a Slave to all your Interests,
Employ your Cunning, I'll assist your Arts;
Cheat all your Friends, but me.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Cheat you?

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Has Mr. Granger done any thing to make him your aversion?
You won't allow him to be a Man of Honour;
Have you a mind to put him to the Tryal?

When you refuse a Man a Commendation that every body gives him, you must pardon me,
If I think, 'tis for some private reason of your own:
Besides, I never knew a Woman declare an unreasonable aversion for a Man in publick, that had not a mind to have a better opinion of him in private.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: What, you are jealous of him?

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Not jealous, Madam: But 'tis a weakness to be too secure: While I rally'd to the Company, I had my Eyes about me, and indeed by what you lookt, or did, or said to him, I cou'd not find out your aversion.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: A very Boyish jealousie indeed! He lost to us, And I was civil to him; nay, civil to his losses, not to him:
I can do more to serve the common cause,
So certain to our Interestâ€”

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: I do believe you can do what you please; and I'll watch your pleasureâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Is your Lord stirring yet, Florence?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: He has been in his Dressing-Room this half hour, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Then 'tis as I wou'd have it; and a fair time for me to go to Bedâ€” I comeâ€”

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Shall we meet this Afternoon?

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Not this Afternoon, I have Business; hardly this Week I fear: I hope I've satisfied your jealousie: you don't know enough of meâ€”

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: I do know enough, enough to satisfie me,
There's no knowing more than she has a mind to:
And all the knowledge our weak search can find,
But proves, there is no knowing Womankind.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Wishwell at her Toylett with Christian.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: PRithee leave sidling, 'tis well enough.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Madam, you wou'd have your things sit handsomly.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Decently, I wou'd; what you call handsomly, is a niceness, wou'd as ill become me, as a Sultana did a fat body, or a high Commode a lean Face; and only serve to make my decays more remarkable.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Will you please to use the Wash.â€”

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p:
I use the Wash! A Woman turn'd of fifty, was ne're design'd to be lookt upon: I may Wash, and Patch, and please my self; cheat my hopes, with the dayly expence of Plaister, and Repairs; No body will take the Tenement off my hands. Men use us, as we use our Spectacles, to draw the Object nearer to the
Sense: Indeed we are the fittest means, to guide and light their dark designs home to their ends on younger Women. No matter for the Character; I live by them, and they shall Love by me.

While I am Mistress of Malepert's Beauty, I am not very sensible of the loss of my own: For her sake I will be Courted: I have so many howd'yees, and invitations in the Morning upon her account; so many visits in the Afternoon; and so many Bows in the Drawing-Room at Night.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: For her sake you have so many Rafflings, and whoever throws most, you win the prize: For her sake, my proud Lord Lofty, who scarce bows to Heaven, cringes to you, and for her sake the whole Town calls you Bawd.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Time has been, when by the merits of my own Faceâ€” but

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I had almost forgot, Madam, Mrs. Lucy was here this Morning, and desires you to remember Mr. Oglewell of the Temple.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: She may rest her self contented; he is not for her turn: Mrs. Siam sent her Maid to his Chambers yesterday, in the Afternoon too, his Man deny'd him at first, but afterwards confest, his Master was in Bed with a fine Gentlewoman (one of the common fine things of the Townâ€” I suppose) and wou'd not be disturb'd.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: How, Madam! pretend to marry Mrs. Lucy for Love, and be in Bed with another!

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Nay, now, he'll hardly marry for Love, since he has found a remedy for Love, without marrying.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Base Man! does not he fear a Judgment will follow him? Had it been a Match, I was to have 50 Pound of her, for putting your Ladyship in mind of it.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: And did the Fool believe I wou'd turn Match-maker in my Old Age?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Why, Madam, 'tis no such Dishonourable Character.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: But 'tis Ridiculous, and that's worse: No, give me an Office, where I may have thanks for what I do: Go, get the Chocolateâ€” and remember I am at home to no body, but Lady Malepert.

'Tis near the time she was to call me for the India-Houses, she turns to more account, than any of my former Acquaintance: She has hitherto been rul'd by me: And I will keep her out of those Gentlemens hands, if I can, who, by engaging her, as deep as they can, into their Interest, will certainly, as soon as they can, take her out of mine. If I may believe her, no body but Lord Lofty has yet been happy: He grows weary of presenting; and must give place to Gamesters, that bid more: Sir Ruff Rancounter offers very fair: While I can keep her to Men, where she can like nothing but their Money, I am safe:
Therefore that Brute shall have her:
But Gayman loves her: She likes him too:
And when the Parties are so far agreed; there's but little work for a third
Person, to bring 'em together. I fear Gayman,

As I shou'd a French Privateer, in the Channel, without a Convoy, and
all my Fortune on board one Vessel: For he's a Master of those thriving Arts, and little Rogueries, that cheat, and please the Women: Then to his Person, Wit, and Industry, he has a certain respectful Impudence in his Behaviour, few Women can find fault with, or resist.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Before I cou'd give your Orders to deny you, Lord Lofty was told you were at home.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: This must be by Malepert's appointment.
Wait on him up.
But now he's out at Court, he shall soon be so with her.
How! Mr. Gayman!

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: 'Tis well you nam'd me, Madam; by the strangeness of your look, I was afraid you had forgot me.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: I am surpriz'd you shou'd use another Name, to be admitted here; where I command you shall always be welcome.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I was sure the Name I borrow'd, wou'd carry me through this Family.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Your own can do as much.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Then 'tis since his disgrace: For, not three days ago, when you deny'd your self to every body, and to me, among the crowd of your unseasonoble Visiters, my Lord Lofty and Lady Malepert, were notoriously above stairs with you; above stairs, in private with you; with you, or without you.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: How, Mr. Gayman! notoriously at my House?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why, yes Faith, Madam, it was very notorious:
And you were so little cautious of concealing it,
Their Pages were at Play, all the afternoon, before the Door: It made a Jest for every body that went by; and wou'd have been apprehended by the very blind Cuckold himself, had he hapned in the way.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, Sir; now you show your self.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why, Faith, I can't help it; I must show my self,

Upon these occasions; 'tis every Honest Man's cause, and duty to be concern'd to find the best things so abus'd; to see a young Ladies Pleasures fall so soon, into the Contempt and Scandal of the Town, thro' indiscretion, or mismannagement:
I don't tax you of either: But the World.â€”

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: I defie the Worldâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: The Flesh, and the Devil too, good Madam:
But they'l get the better of us all.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: And you, the worst of Devils. What of the World?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why People you know are apt to prate:
And when a Woman of Experience, as you may be, engages in these Affairs, the World expects a Conduct suitable to your Grave Character:
All the miscarriages of an Intriegue are lay'd on you, the Lovers are call'd Fools;
And you have a, worsec Name.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: I see you come to rail, I laugh at you.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I came to make you merry: Laugh with me, if you please; we'll Laugh at other People:
While he was in favour, I grant you, he might be a Friend; and there was
Reason good for serving him:
But I know you are truer to the interest of the Drawing-Room, than to think any Man, that's in disgrace, can be a Friend.
Since my Good Lord is down, ev'n let him lye,
Another Man may rise out of his fall:
You can't want Friends:
I have a hard-harted Father must dye at last;
And then I can be what you think a Friend,
Able to come up to your price of thanks: Come,
Not to get a habit of it, do a generous thing,
And let me once speak well of you.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Come, come, I'm in the secret, and therefore fittest to be trusted now: the Lady's an out-lying Deer; I know, you have been accessary to some of her scapes already; and can help her over the Pale, upon occasion again, to serve a Friend, Mrs. Wishwell.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: We are both beholden to you.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: If I am not to be oblig'd to her, upon your account,
'Tis but staying till my Betters are serv'd,
And then, as you mannage matters,
Every Man may hope to have her in his turn.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Madam, my Lady Malepert's coming up.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: How, Madam!

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: To hear how kindly you can speak of her.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Forgive what I have said, my Fortune, Interest, Life, and all you shall command.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: I wou'd command your Tongue.
Thou Charming Creature!
Befor ever thus, thus Dear, thus Young, thus ever killing Fair?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dear Wishwell, I fear I have tir'd thy patience.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Doting to this degree, I needs must languish: But now l have you thus.â€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Flattering Devil!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My passionate Gallant!

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: That Title you may allow me, without injuring your Lordâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: There the question hangs.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How! Mr. Gayman! you're a Stranger here.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I'm sorry for that, Madam; I am every where an humble Servant of your Ladyships.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Wou'd the Devil had her for coming so unseasonably:
I can't avoid leaving 'em together: But the opportunity shall do him little good:
Your Ladyship will allow me a minute, and I'll be with you agenâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: That minute must be mine: And let a minute tell you,
What all my Life can ne're enough explain, how much I value you.
I wont believe 'tis from your own Design, that I'm thus us'd:
I know I've Enemies, but wonnot think you can be one of 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I ne're can be your Enemy.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: O, no! they're outward all, not near this tender Breast,
And most unworthy to possess your Heart;
That Heart, which once you said, was wholly mine.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And was not that a fault?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: It was, to break your word.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, did I say so?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Because then it pleas'd you, to speak a Truth that charm'd me to be yours: And yours I must be, use me as you will:
But being yours.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, did I meet you here?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: To tell me where I next shall meet you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why will you press me thus to what will ruine me?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: With Wishwell, I wou'd have it.â€”

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If you can think it fit.â€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: There's nothing fit without you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: At Siam's, this Afternoon, we Raffle there.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I Raffle for a Heart.â€”

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mrs. Siam, you're in your round of Visitation, I see.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: I joy to find your Ladyship here: I have the sweetest things;
I have 'em in the next room to shew you. Good Lord!
Mr. Gayman! how came you here? Who-ever's the better for your Company,
I'm sure, I shall have no reason to thank you for't, at this time.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Nor I neither, Pox take himâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, pray?

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: The matter! why, a Jealous, Old, Coxcombly Fellow, (that ought to be a Cuckold, if I had Womanhood enough about me, to make him one) is matter enough for all the misfortunes, that can fall upon a Woman, of my publick Employment.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: What! my Noble Captain Drydrubb, your Husband?

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the Nobel Captain, as you call him:
Wou'd he were a Captain now, to be Commanded into Flanders, that I might hope to be rid of him

But I'm ev'n well enough serv'd, I must have a Souldier, with a Pox to him: a Man of Honour, as he calls hpimself, to Command me: One, that has out-liv'd the memory of being a Corporal, in the Civil Wars; and has borrow'd the Title of a Captain, only to run in Debt with.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: He's Man of Honour enough, to be jealous it seems.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he's Jealous enough to be a Man of Honour, if that will make him one: But he's Jealous of himself, I suppose, and his own Honour; and that makes him Jealous of me, and mine: But l've a plaguy Life with him, that's the Truth on't;
He follows me all over the Town,
Dogs me wherever I go: All this live-long Morning

He has been at my heels: He says I run a gadding after the Fellows, and if he finds out my Haunts, he swears he'l pepper me: Now if he has seen your Servants at the Door, the whole World shall never perswade him, but I came upon an Assignation with your Worship; and 'twill hardly be in the power of a Guinny, to make him quiet again.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Poor Siam! I vow she has a dismal time on't:

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: A dismal time on't, indeed, if your Ladyship knew all; but for Gods-sake, Mr. Gayman, as you tender the Reputation, and quiet of a poor Woman, that have been Younger in my time, be so kind nowâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Well, Mrs. Siam, I will be so kind.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Else this overcharg'd Blunderbuss, will have the Impudence to come in, and let flye among the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I'le deliver you this time from his Jealousie;
I am a Slave to the Interest of your Sex:
Your Servant, Ladies.â€”

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Well, this Mr. Gayman is a civil Gentleman in appearance, and that's as much as a Lady can desire in a Young Man: Truly I'm oblig'd to him.
Shall I bring in the Stuffs, Madam? They are the newest things; I'm sure they'l please your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Some of your stale Ware, Siam.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Upon the Faith of a Christian, Madam, they never saw this side of the World yet; they're just out of the Indian House, and never were open'd to any one, but this Morning, to my Lady Kill-Chairman; She indeed is my very good Customer, and bought four pieces of 'em for a Mantoa.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For her whole Family sure, four pieces!

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: We'll look upon 'em, in the next Room, if you please.
But, Siam, what have you done about our Raffle?
Are there Subscribers enow?

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: I want but one, Madam: I have got a very Honest Generous Gentleman, to make one, Sir Ruff Rancounter;
If he wins, he'll scorn to carry any thing out of the Company; some of the
Ladies will be the better for him.
Leave these things to me: The Men I provide for you, at my House, shall be Men of Honour, I assure you, and for the purpose you design 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What purpose can such a Beast, as Rancounter, be design'd for among the Women?

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Why, like a Beast, to bear the burthen of your Expences upon your Pleasures.
None but such Beasts will bear 'em: Think on that.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I hate him.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: I wou'd not have you Love him: Love your self,
And then you'l Love nothing but your Interest.
Come, come, a 1000 Pounds may answer for the Man:
'Tis but suffering a little of his Company; and why not a little of his, as well as more of your Husbands?
They're Beasts alike: Only this, in proportion, bids more to be receiv'd by you.

Then he can do you no Injury, either in your Quiet, or your Fame: For you can no more be in Love with him, (which is a great Blessing in these Affairs) than the Town can think, you ever allow'd him, to be in Love with you, and is not a Thousand Pound, a round Summ, for doing so little, and suffering nothing?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But why shou'd I do any thing against my Inclinations? I don't want the Money.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, every Woman wants a Thousand Pound:
And for your Inclinations, if you allow them to get the better of you, you are undone:
There are a great many pretty Gentlemen to be had;
But what will you get by any of 'em in the end?
Just so much Experience, and Repentance for your pains: You may be in
Love with a Man, that has it in his Temper to be in Love with half the
Town; as all the Young Men are.
And how will it agree with the Pleasure of your Pride,
Or the pride of your Pleasure, to be forsaken?
No, no, no Love: We'll learn that of the Men:
For Love is Nature's Appetite Diseas'd:
Where we have no Concern, we're always pleas'd.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.p: St. Iames's Park.
div.stage: Sir Ruff meeting Gayman and Garnish.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Did you see, Lord Malepert?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: What! must it be a Tilt, Sir Ruff?

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: No, no, hang Fighting among Friends:
I have other Business for him; of another Nature,
Gentlemen; I make Love to his Wife.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: How? how? pray recollect your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Nay, not that I think her any better than her Chambermaid: 'Tis the Woman does my business, and not the Lady: I had rather have a prudent Practiser of the Trade, to use as I think fit; than a Gentlewoman (that only does it now and then, for her Diversion) to use me as she pleases.
But, you know, a Man in this Town, is no body, without the Reputation of a
Quality-Entriegue:
And all that I do it for, is to talk of in Company;
And be better respected by the Women:
For you know, they generally judge,
Just as other Women have judg d before 'em.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: But if the Entriegue be only on your side.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Sir, I wou'd have you to know, 'tis on her side too:
Gayman, thou art a pretty Fellow, and shalt be my Confident: There's no Living, without Communicating matters of this kind, to have both parties the better for 'em.
But, Mr Garnish, to convince you,
The Husband's strangely fond of me, and you know,
That always proceeds from the good Opinion of the Wife.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I may make use of this.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: But besides, I have made Madam Wishwell, my Friend:
It costs me Money indeed; but she takes the troublesome part off my Hands: She makes Love for me; I'm only to stand by what she says:
She sends me word, we are to Raffle at Siam's in the Afternoon.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: But, my Lord, and you are fall'n out.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: That's no matter, if I cou'd meet him.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Here he comes, ready for your purpose.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Give me thy Hand, dear Bully; Faith, I'm sorry you provok'd me to use you so untowardly.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Really, Sir Ruff, and so am I, with all my Heart, I meant no harm, I vow and swear: If I had not thought you my Friend, I wou'd not have pretended to be witty in your Company:
But Faith, and Troth, you were bloody Angry.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Come, come, shall we Dine together?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: With all my Heart; upon Condition, you'l go with me to Siam's in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Nay, that's but reasonable.â€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Then be it so; I'le go along with you.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Well, Siam's the best Woman in the World:
She's the rarest Company, and has all the News.
Then she's so fond of me, that I verily believe I spend above a Thousand a
Year at her House.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Nay, Faith, then you have Reason.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: I vow, I shou'd be the worst Man in the World,
If I did not Love her,
She has done so handsomely by my Wife.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: As how, pray?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Why, she heard a Noble Lord, and a Great Man at Whitehall, say, he was in Love with her: And what do you think this good Creature did?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why, pray perhaps, that she might resist the Temptation.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O Foolish! pray? No, quite contrary:
She came to her next morning, and told her of it;
That she might be sure to avoid him.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: No doubt, that was the Reason.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: But, my Lord, you are not there so often as you us'd.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Why since her Marriage, the House is turn'd upside down: what do People Marry for, but to live easy with every body? When there's no danger of a Rival.
Methinks a Man should think every one his Friend:
I'm sure 'tis the Maxim of my Family.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: It should be the Maxim of every Man, That's Born to your Fortune, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: But the Old Captain, you must know, has got it into his Head, to be Jealous of me, and is grown so troublesome; he can't endure a Witty Man shou'd come into his Doors.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: You have giv'n him Cause, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Nay indeed, if Mrs. Siam was to be had, I believe, I stand as fair for her, as any body:
But I never had the least dishonourable Thought of her;
Never saw any thing bare of her, above her Knee:
An inviolable Friendship I must own for her;
I Love her mightily.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I thought there was something in't.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Ay, ay, no doubt on't. But we shall lose our Dinner.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Nay, I wou'd not lose my Dinner for more than I'le speak of, at this time: my Wife is very regular at her Meal:
If I chance to lose a Meal, she says,
I an't my own Man agen in a week after.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Nor your Wife's neither, my Lord; come let's be gone.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: 'Tis almost One: Granger said he wou'd be here.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: That Friend of yours, is a pleasant, snarling Fellow, And a good Companion: 'Tis pity he's so very peevish.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: He has a Thousand good Qualities, but they have all a tang of his testy Humour, that shows it self in all he says, and does; like a drop of Oyl left it a Flask of Wine, in every Glass you taste it.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Here the Gentleman comes to answer for himself.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Sir, my Lord, commanded me to tell you, Company Dines with him, And he desires you'd please to be there.
Well, well. [Exit Footman.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Well, well.

Zounds! a Man had as good be ty'd to a Stake, and baited like Tom Dove, on an Easter Monday, as be the necessary appurtenance of a Great Man's Table; they make me as much their own, as if I were part of their side-board.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: What's the matter, Mr. Granger?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why in such a Passion?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Passion! why they use me, as if I had none about me:
They won't let me be my own Man 24 Hours together.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: That's hard indeed: But pray, who does encroach upon your Liberty?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Who? Why who shou'd dare? But they who may do any thing: Here's the new Favourite Summons me to Dine with him: He sends me word there will be Company; and, I suppose, designs to serve me up, as part of the Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Now, wou'd many an Honest Fellow be proud of this Invitation, and think his Fortune made by't.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Why, I have known many an Honest Fellow proud of the Pox; but my Ambition does not lye that way, nor my Inclination at present: But thither I must go, tho' I was engag'd to my Ld. Lofty.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Will he admit of no excuse?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: No, plague on't, his Messages are like Subpaena's; I may stay away, if I think fit; but I shall pay a swinging Fine for my contempt.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: 'Tis not a Month since he was in your Favour, and Lofty cou'd not get a good word from you.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: And 'tis not yet a Fortnight, since he was mean enough to accept of an Employment; and Lofty had the Soul to part with three.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Sure, Granger, thou lovest a nodding wall; that will bury thee in its ruins;
Tho' it never gave thee shelter, while it stood:
As no one was the better for Lofty's Greatness, methinks it shou'd be difficult to be concern'd for his Disgrace:
I'm sure I'le condole with no Man, that wou'd never give me cause to rejoice with him.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: He mended every day.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: No Faith, he kept up his Character to the last:
And had his Politicks, and Honesty, been put into the Scale, the ballance had been even.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: This is ungenerous.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: 'Tis what you have said of him, within this Month, and still the Man's the fame.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: If you must rail, let the new Favourite be the Subject.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why, what's his fault?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Why, he's a Favourite; that will make faults, if it find none.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p:
You may distinguish the Man from the Favourite:
He's ne're the worse for having it in his power to do good Offices:
Besides his Company's good; his Table easie; and, Granger, he has always been a friend to you.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: A Friend to me! A Tyrant. Has he not carry'd me about, like Bajazet; and made me talk too?

Zounds! does he take me for a Parrot? the Bird deserves his meat, and cleaning of his Cage; that talks for't. You, who love the Company, and Tyranny of Courtiers, much good may do you with it: For my part, 'tis a Hell to me; and I'll keep out on't, as long as I canâ€”

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Do'st: talk of Hell, Old Boy? There's a Parson in the bottom on't
I believe: For there's no Hell, no Purgatory, no Devil, but of the Clergy's providing.
What! thou hast Marry'd some old libidinous Gentlewoman?â€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Not I indeed, Sir; I have occasion sufficient to be out of humour; without having a Wife, Young, or Old, to provoke me: You must guess agen.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Not I, Sir, I shan't guess agen: You may have it, for the keeping, if you won't tell us what's the matter with you:
But you say you're a Whore-Master?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Not you, Sir, why may be then you are not so honest a Man:
But if you are not a Marry'd Man, you must be a Whore-Master: And why you shou'd be out of humour, who carry all the Women before you,
I can't tell: Cuckoldy Husbands indeed, that come after you, have something to provoke 'em: Grant us patience, I say.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why how now, Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why how now! ha! are you there, Sir?
Can't all the Town suffice you, Sir? but you must be running after my Domestick, ferriting in my Borrough?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I, Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, you, no Captain: For all your cunning, I have found out your haunt, your meeting place: Will no less a Bawd, than Mrs. Wishwell, serve your turn? But I see the Ambition of the Boy; by Pompey, I smoke you: Why, what an Impudent Fellow are you to think of making a Cuckold of a Captain?
Did you ever hear of a Captain, that was a Cuckold, Sir?
'Twas in the Parliament Army, if you did, that I can tell you.
A Parliament Captain might be a Cuckold indeed;
But 'twas because he had not the King's Commission, to protect his Wife then.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: There were some Cuckolds in that Army, I believe, who made use of their Horns to toss the Cavaliers out of the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But I was always on the King's sideâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Beaten? Capt. Beaten! ay, sometimes beaten, Sir:
'Tis no such wonder for a Captain to be beaten, I hope:

But I'll not be a Cuckold, Sir, not be beaten by a Distaff, a Wife: Have
I brought my Honour from Edghill, both the Newbury's and Marston-Moor, nay, and from Worcester too, to lose in an Indian House? Then Fortune is my Foe,

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Faith, Captain, your Honour's safe for me:
But I cou'd tell you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What can you tell me, Sir, I know enough already;
And more than I care to know.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why, I cou'd tell you, who attempts your Honour,
If you had temper to hear meâ€”

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Temper to hear you! why I'm as temperate a Tom-titt; as mild as May: Prithee tell me, good Boy, who?

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Nay, now you're engag'd in Honour to tell him.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I am loath to make a Division among Friends;
But I must acquit my self, and truly I have observ'd some winks, and passing familiarities between Lord Malepert, and your Wife.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, I thought there was no good towards, in his coming so often to the House: But does that snivelling Pea-Chick think to make a Cuckold of me? Who have seen all the service of Christendom, from the meeting the Scotch Army at Coldstream, to the merry meeting at Hounslow-Heath.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Nay, I have seen Mrs. Wishwell carry Whispers between 'em.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I'll demolish, by Pompey, I'll break her Windows and turn over my old Punk to the Sessions, to answer the Battery: But for that beardless, shambling, whay-fac'dâ€”
They are to raffle at our House this Afternoon:
This is Wishwell's design to bring 'em together;
But I shall part them with a Clap of Thunder, by Pompey.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Well said, old Baskitbilt.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, faith, I'll swinge 'em: I remember your Dammee-Boys, your Swashes, your Tuquoques, and your Titire-Tues: Have us'd the Fleece, and Speering's: Thrown Clunch at a whole Table, where half of ' emwore Velvet Patches: Had drank my Tun of Brandy, before this puleing Puppy's Father tasted Milk. I'll ransack 'em, by Pompey.

sp.speaker: Gam.
sp.p: Can we assist you, Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Not that I care what any Man can do with the old Jade:
But I won't be a Cuckold, in my Old Age, Gentlemen, I won't be a Cuckold: I can make a thrust stillâ€” faâ€” faâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: All vigour to the stump!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And, by Pompey, they shall find I am.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Will you dine with us, Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Dine with you! you must lend me a Guinny then,
One little Guinny; or I must go home to the old Iezebel, and compound for a Cuckoldom,
By staying abroad as long as she pleases.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Here's that shall prevent it. [Gives him a Guinny.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: God a Mercy, Boy!

By Pompey, now the day's agen, our own:
We'll go, and cherish our selves with a good Dinner,
Some Wine, and much Nants,
And then resolv'd for War, we'll boldly try,
Who beats up my Wife's Quarters, he, or I. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.p: Lady Susan's Lodgings.
div.stage: Enter Lady Susan, Maria, and Lord Malepert.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: COme, dear Mariaâ€”

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your Ladyship's Lodgings are so neat!

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Siam and I fancy'd all the Furniture:
We ran about to Shops three days together:
I love running about mightily.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: True, Nephew, you paid Coach hire; but I vow, Maria, 'twas every bit of it my own fancy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis very well fancy'd: and every thing in such Order!

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O law! you know 'tis my day; and then Mr. Granger and the rest of 'em will certainly be here.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Granger's a Wit: He and I are very great;
And I love a Wit mightily.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, Madam, you're oblig'd to Mr. Granger.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Jesu! but, dear Maria, tell me,
When, where, and how; I long to know.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Last Night at my Lady Malepert's.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Yes, I vow, and my Wife srump'd all the while, and yet did not say one word.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Well, go on, dear Child, I'm impatientâ€”

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He said you were the only Lady in Town that understood Behaviour, and good Breeding.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O law! and did he?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Yes, I vow, our Family was always remarkable for good breeding.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Dear Nephew, don't interrupt her: Well, dear Childâ€”

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He said Experience had ripen'd you to Womanâ€”

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Yes, I vow, my Aunt was five and forty last Lammas.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Nay, Nephew, know when to hold your Tongue: Come, Mariaâ€”

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But that of all things, he despis'd those unfledg'd Creatures; the Town calls Beauties, a Company of unexperienc'd Girls, without the knowledge of Conversation, in which your Ladyship excell'd.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Nay, my Aunt can talk as much as the best of us.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Crimine! this was strangely obliging.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then he said you had the sweetest Page; and he was always drest so prettilyâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Poor dear Iano. And did he like the Child? He shall see him in his Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: But you forget, Maria, he said happy the Man that were in that Child's place; and figh'd so sillilyâ€”

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then looking scornfully at all the the Ladiesâ€”

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Yes, and upon my Wife too; I assure you, she took it bloody ill of him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He swore no Lady had Charms like yours, nor set 'em off so wellâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: He has not seen me in my new Mantoa yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then rav'd on your Complexion; and for your Eye-browsâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O law! I hope he knows nothing of them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: They were the Strings of Cupid's Bow;
Your Eyes the only Arrows.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: And did he say all this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, and laught at you. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Yes, I vow, did he, and really was very foolishâ€”

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: To see how out of countenance we were to hear it. [Jano enters.

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.p: Madam, Mr. Granger and Mr. Gayman are coming up.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Lord! what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What! afraid to be seen with your Aunt?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: No, I vow now, I an't afraid: but I wou'd not have my Wife know it for the World tho'.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Well, Nephew, go into my Closet:
There's Quarles upon the Japan Table for you.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: What the Book with Pictures! nay, then, 'tis well enough; I'll go in, divert my self. [Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Divert himself! Jesu! did you ever hear such an unseemly Expression before Ladies?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Unseemly, Madam!

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O law! Child, he had even as good ha' told us what he was going about: But, dear Maria, pull down my Mantoa; they're just a coming.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Mr. Granger, Mr. Gayman, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I never saw any thing so pretty as your Ladyships Sconces.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: You're so obliging: And how do you like'em, Mr. Granger?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: As they are your Ladyship's I must admire 'em.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: They were made in France, I assure you, by Madam's own Workmanâ€” Child, bid my Woman set Chairsâ€” [Mrs. Judy sets Chairs.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Wou'd we might have her Company, instead of the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Your Ladyship's Woman's very pretty.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: And has a World of Wit, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: There's no body so much set off by a handsom Woman, as your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O law! that's particularâ€” [Aside.
But, Mr. Granger, do you think her pretty?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: By reflection from your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Still paticularâ€” [Aside.
Mr. Granger, shall I beg a word with you? [They all rise.
'Tis Business; I hope the Company will pardon me.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: What an affected doating Fool's this? How can you bear her?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I must be civil to her for the sake of her Relations.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: You'll be at Siam's about five.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll not fail.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I'll ask for youâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Never to be forgiv'nâ€”
But, Mr. Gayman, have you seen the Stuffs at Siam's? there are three or four the sweetest Pieces: I bought the Red and Silver for a Night Gown.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: 'Twill certainly become your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Pinks and Lillies: exactly her Complexion.

sp.speaker: L. Su
sp.p: O law! Sir! Well, I wonder Trickitt is not come yet; I have seen her almost these two hours: But, Jesu! there's a Coach stopt; I hope 'tis hers.

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.p: 'Tis my Lady Trickitt's; she's just Landed.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Landed! pray mind, Mr. Granger, how prettily he expresses it; he says she's Landed.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Proper, and apt indeed, were it out of a Kennel.

div.stage: [L. Trickitt aloud from the bottom of the Stairs, answered by Lady Susan, Trickitt enters.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Suâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Trickitâ€”
Dear, dear Creature!

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Dear; dear Suky!

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: How the Monkies cling together!

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Well, Trickitt, this was Barbarously done, I vow and swear now, neither to see me, nor let me hear from thee in two whole hours: As I hope to breathe now, I was just going to write thee a Scolding Letter.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Nothing but Business, and my Lord's Commands could have prevented me.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Mr. Garnish, your Servant.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: O, Mr. Garnish! you can tell us: Does Sir Symphony hold forth to Night?

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: He'll tell you himself immediately, Madam: I met him at the end of the Street; and he told me, he had but five Visits to make in his way hither, and wou'd be with you in an Instant.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Well, I vow, 'tis a Civil Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: You speak of him with some concern, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Who, I, Sir? no I vow, a filthy unmannerly Fellow,
And if he had not the Fiddles, now and then, wou'd be good for nothing.
I abhor him, I vow I do: O law! what had I like to ha' done?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Your Ladyship, and Lady Trickitt design to be at his Musick, I hope, notwithstanding this aversion?

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p:
What! on my day? Jesu! Mr. Granger, what do you take me
for? Yet I love Musick to an extravagance, I vow now; but the World, Mr. Granger, what wou'd the World say?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: You're above their Censure, Madam: the receiv'd Opinion of your good breeding will justify your Ladyship in any thing.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Jesu! Trickitt, how Mr. Granger mistakes the matter?
'Tis not that I fear to commit an errour in good breeding,

Not I, I assure you; but if I shou'd be so light, to go to publick Places, when all the World is sensible 'tis my day, they must needs think 'twere an Assignation, and that for a Lady of my Qualityâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: Ladies, your most obeysant
Servant: I'm come to you with an invitation from the Muses; all the
World have promised me the honour of their Company; and yet if I am refus'd your Ladyships, I shall think my House a Solitude.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: You can have no Company of mine to Night, Sir:
I must use him scurvily before Mr. Granger,
Else he may be jealous; and I would not have 'em quarrel here for the World.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: Cruel Creature! But is there no hopes, Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, pray be quiet; Lord, can't you let a body alone? pray what have I to do with your hopes? Really, Mr. Granger, this Fellow is a forward impertinent Fop, so he is.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, his forwardness does not proceed from any encouragement you have given him?

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Jesu! Sir, I give a Man encouragement!

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I only speak my Fears, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: You're so Obliging, Sirâ€”
Well, this is past dispute.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: What have you there, Sir Symphony?

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.l: Why, this is a Catalogue of the Ladies
I Visit, Ogle, and say soft things to:
Seven and Fifty, Widows, Wives, and Maids:
And if I don't succeed with some of 'em;
I have been a Civil Person to little purpose.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I'll follow you immediatelyâ€”

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll take my timeâ€”

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.p: Madam, Mrs. Prattle has sent
Her servant, to desire your Ladyship to carry her to the Park to morrow Night.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: How prettily the Child delivers his Message?
sp.l: Pray kiss him, Mr. Granger, he has the sweetest breath; this will give an opportunity to take off my Kiss, [Aside] You are mightily oblig'd to Mr. Granger,
Child, you should make him a visit now and then;
But, Child, present my service to her, and beg her to pardon, or rather pity my misfortune:
For I han't one day free 'till Tuesday Sennight;
And then, if she pleases, she may Command meâ€”
But hold, Childâ€” tell her, Trickitt and I intend to go to Shops, and see Sights, all day long on Monday,
Not one shall 'scape us, from the Fat Girl in St. Martin's-Lane, (Where we intend to begin at Nine exactly) to the Embroidered Prince of Gilolo,
If she's for a Frolick, Child, we shall be glad of her Company [Ex. Jano.
This is a good hint for Mr. Granger, we shall be sure of himâ€”
Well, don't you think Prattle has a world of Wit?

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: She's a most Exquisite Lady, and oneâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: I did not ask your Opinion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: I find I am unfortunate to day, and will walk off with my disgrace, in hopes of better timesâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: But your Opinion, Gentlemen, you are Judges.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: She says a great deal, Madamâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: And very well too, I vow, and swear now;
But what say you, Mr. Granger?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Faith, I think she's all talk, and no Company.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O law! Why she plays at little Games to a miracle.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: The blind Horse is fittest for the Mill.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: She's a Lady of great Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Nay, she's the universal Crony of the Sex:
Not a Female from Thirteen, to Five and Thirty, can be a Week in Town, without a Visit from her, which makes her very convenient to her Male Relations.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O law! Mr. Granger! I vow I believe her as Virtuous as my self; but then she Sings, and Plays upon the Virginals so sweetly, and Dances Country Dances.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Nay, doubtless she has all her motions to a miracle; and for Ioan Saundersonâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Law! Mr. Granger, you're so strangely S'terical:
I believe you laugh at us all behind our backs.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Fools I laugh at to their faces:
But such as your Ladyshipâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Jesu! Mr. Granger.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Wit, Beauty, and Good Breeding, Madam, command respect; 'twas Death to touch the Ark.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Well, he's strangely obliging!â€”
What, leaving us already, Mr. Gayman?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Business calls me from my pleasure, Madam.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I'm sure there's something in'tâ€” [Observing Trickitt, & Grang.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Mr. Granger, you are melancholly, o'th' sudden,
Are not you well? will you have some of my Milk-water?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: My Fever's in the Spirits, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Nay, there's something extraordinary;
We all observe a Change, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: I'll lay my life, he's in Love, Child.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: I hope he is, to be reveng'd of him;

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Well, is it so, Mr. Granger?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: In Company, like this, 'tis difficult to live without a Passionâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.l: Well, this is a plain Declaration.
We must not force him to a Confession;
'Twill press his modestly too far, I vow now.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: The Confession's but too plain;
Tho' she mistakes it.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Why so sullen, Sir?

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Have I not Cause?

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: You mistake it, but I shall find a time.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: I shall find it for you.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: We interrupt the Ladies.
Let's take the hint, and leave 'emâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.l: O law! Gentlemen, I beg a Thousand Pardonsâ€”
What gone! Well, I'm so glad I have thee to my self:
Child, if Company comes, I have the Head-ach,
And am laid downâ€”
I have a secret of prodigious Importance to tell thee;
Well, 'tis some Mens misfortune to judge amiss:
But what if Granger shou'd be in Love?

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Wou'd that be an Errour in his Judgment?

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.l: O law! you take me wrong:
But what if he shou'd love a Friend of yours?
Well, I'll keep thee no longer in suspense;
He has a good Estate, besides his place,
And I'm confident you wou'd not be against it.

sp.speaker: L. Trick.
sp.p: What! a good Estate?

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: I Crimine! I see I must be plain with thee:
But did not you observe how Civil he was to me?

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: 'Twas his good Breeding.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: But from a Man, that's thought moroseâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign of a clear Skie;
No Clouds to raise the Spleen.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: In short he loves me, and has e'en as good as told me so:
And I vow and swear I design to let him know his Passion is not unsuccessful: I have a Plot upon him:
My pretty little Iano shall visit him, as of himself, the Child shall give him my Song, and tell him, all the Servants say, he's in Love with me, and that you know will force a Declaration.

sp.speaker: L. Trick.
sp.p: No doubt, Child.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Well, we shall so laugh: And then you come to visit my Lady Susan Grangerâ€” and then I return thy visit, and your Servant tells you, my Lady Susan Granger's Page has sent up word, his Lady's just a landing from her Chairâ€” and then you say, your Ladyships, my Dear, is the prettyest Equipage in Townâ€” and then I sayâ€” well I shall be so happy:
For Mr. Granger resolves to eat in Plate.

sp.speaker: L. Trick.
sp.p: Has he told you so?

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Jesu! no; but then he laughs at all the Fools; And will bring me home the Lampoons: But I must instruct the Child; come hither Iano: Prithee, md Dear, pardon me a little.

sp.speaker: L. Trick.
sp.l: That my very good Friend shou'd be so blind!
She'll be something long in her Instructions;
I'll into the Closetâ€” how! Suky! [Looks in, and starts.
A Man a sleep in thy Closet?

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.l: O law! I vow and swear now, 'tis my Nephewâ€”
He was here before the Company came, and you know since our quarrel, his Wife won't give him leave to come to me.

Well, I wonder at her irregular fancy in Love, and Friendship: How can she endure an antiquated Lofty, while there's a Youthful Gayman to be had? Or make a Confidence with such a Creature, as Wishwell, that's past the taste of a partie quarre?

sp.speaker: L. Trick.
sp.p: Why my Lord, Lord Malepert.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O law! Aunt! what's the matter?
sp.stage: Enter my Lord frighted, and rubbing his eyes.
sp.p: Why did you leave the Door unlockt?

I'm sure I made the back Door so fast, that Mrs. Iudy cou'd not get in, for all she had the Key: And I thought you had been old enough, to look to your fore-dore your self. I'll swear, if I had thought you wou'd serve me so, I wou'd ha' gone down the back Stairs, let the Footmen have said what they please, so I wou'd. But, good Madam, not a word of seeing me here.

sp.speaker: L. Trick.
sp.p: Well, trust you to my Discretion.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Nay, as for your Discretion, Madam, I know you:
You have Discretion enough to win all our Money, I'll take your word for any thing but an Alpieu.

sp.speaker: L. Trick.
sp.p: Well, Dear Suky, adieuâ€” nay no ceremonyâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Jesu? can you be my Friend, and desire I shou'd be so unbredâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Trick.
sp.p: You disoblige me eternally, if you stir a step farther.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: To obey you, my Dearâ€”

Well for all 'tis my day, Iudy and I will go masqued to Sir Symbony'sâ€” Trickitt, Trickittâ€” Gads me, I have forgot half my business with herâ€” I must go in, and write her a Letter, before the Child comes backâ€”

div.stage: Scene changes to Grangers Lodgings. Granger and Garnish.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: This is but an ill return, Mr. Granger, for she's a grat admirer of yours.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Pox on her, she's so obliging; and takes such Pains to inform me, of what I don't care to know.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: She calls you her dull Amintor, and says, for a well-bred Person, you are certainly the most modest Creature breathing:
She knows you're in Love with her, and has giv'n you a 1000 opportunities, to declare your Passion, which your respectfull bashfullness has still prevented you, from laying hold of.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: From laying hold of! I am for laying hold of nothing, she has about her, unless it be pretty Mrs. Iudy: No, no, she speaks too plain to be understood: She may be in earnest, upon this Subject, to her self; but she will always be a jest to me. Not but I shall put her to the right use.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Not the use you think of, if I can help it.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: What's the business?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady Susan Malepert's little Page is below, and says he comes to make your Honour a visit.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Bring him up:
Does she send her Embassadour already?
She has scarce had time to draw up his Credentials: Prithee step into my Dressing-Room, while I give audience:
My little Ganymede!
Thou'rt welcome; this was kindly done.

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.p: But if you shou'd tell my Lady, she'd never forgive me.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: How do you know, Child?

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.p: She told me so; for she knows nothing of my coming.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Indeed Child?

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.p: No indeed now: Nay, and if you shou'd tell her, I say she talks kindly of you; she'd kill me, so she wou'd.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: No sure, Child, she cou'd not have the heart.

sp.speaker: Iano,
sp.p: Yes indeed, she bad me say so: And then I must not give you this Song, unless you promise to give't me agen; for she said a fine Lady of Quality writ it, upon a very good Friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: But I may take a Copy?

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.p: She said nothing of that, I believe you may.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: When will Lady Trickitt be with your Lady, Child?

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.l: She's with her two or three times every day:
And then the Servants say your Honour loves my Lady, and intend to
Marry her, and be our Master.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: That were too great an Honour for me, Child: Does not Lady Trickitt send for thee sometimes to sing to her?

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.p: I go there by and by: But my Lady will be so impatient to know what your Honour says; for indeed she does not know a word of my being here.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: That's a good Child: But thy Lady's a fine, accomplish'd Lady; I dare not presume to think of her. But here's the Song again; my Friend shall write an Answer.

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.p: And shall I tell my Lady so from your Honour?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: She knows nothing of the matter, Child: But there's a Guiney. to buy Cherries, and be sure you call on my Lady Trickitt, in your way home, and give her this: And if you bring me an Answer, I have another, Guiney in my Pocket for you: So, that's my good Child, thy Lady will want thee.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what News from the Lady?

sp.speaker: Grang,
sp.p: Nothing extraordinary; she has play'd the Fool, and writ a Song, as most People do, that are in love: Pray read it, 'tis all her own, I assure you.

lg.l: PRithee, my Dear, do not be so peevish
To her, that takes thy part:
Altho' thy Eyes, and thy Tongue so theevish,
Have stole away her Heart.
For know, my Dear, it is I that love thee,
Most Passionately:
And if thou't do as it doth behove thee,
I'll thank thee heartily.
Then, prithee Dear, let me know the Morning,
When thou and I shall Wed:
For I, by that, shall guess the Evening
When we shall go to Bed.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Tender and Passionate! and a very just Conclusion!

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Shall we look into the Play?

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: I'll wait on youâ€”
Till I know the Success of your Letter.

sp.speaker: Captain Drydrubb

l.hi: Once I lay with another Man's Wife,
And I lay in a great deal of danger:

sp.l: But now I have gotten a Wife of my own.â€”
