div.p: And so I have, by Pompey; and here must I, to get a solitary Guiney, now and then, to keep up Loyalty, with a Cup of Cordial Nants, be forc'd to see a Parcel of Ague-fac'd Puppies come perking and pruning after my damn'd Jade: Pox on her, can't she sell off all her Foolish Trumpery at once, and set up an honest Sociable Cellar, where a gang of Generous, Old, Crimson-gill'd, grumbling Cavaliers, may take a Pipe and a Quartern, and my Honour never be concern'd.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, good Captain, the Company will be here in a wink, as a body may say: Can't you go take a civil walk in our Fields, and leave me to carry on my Occupation.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Occupation, with a Pox to you! What, must I be turn'd out from under my own Roof, to make Room for a Company of strutting, cocking Coxcombs? To help to carry on your Occupation! Ounds! I'll not stir a foot: I'll see who dares command, where I am Master, I will, by Pompey.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: But pray consider, Captainâ€”

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That's good, I gad, talk of Consideration to a Captain: Why dost not thou know that I have been undone for three Kings, without any Consideration? Why I han't one single Tester left to purchase a civil Qaartern: And how should I consider, with a Pox to you?

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Consider this then, Captainâ€”

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, this is sense now; this I can consider: And prithee, Dolly, do thou consider too; for Honour, thou know'st, is the nearest and dearest thing to a Souldier: So prithee carry thy self like the Wife of my Bosom: For, look thee, Child, 'tis not any concern for thy Carcass that makes me speakâ€”

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Thank you, good Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, by Pompey, 'tis my Honour; and look to't, you had best, for I may return most rouzie-bouzie, and if I find you have injur'd me, I'll swinge you all, by Hercules.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: So get thee gone.
Betty, is the China carry'd to my Lady Trickitt's?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: The Fellow's come back, Madam.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Has he brought the Money?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No, she bid him call next Week.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Gads bodikins! had not she promis'd me ready Money, I had never parted with my Goods: Well, there's no faith in these upstart great Ladies: Now must I make forty jaunts to t'other end o'th' Town; and then I shall be paid in crack't Money; and pay Poundage into the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: She said you were oblig'd to her for the Custom of the Court, and owed her a good turn.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: And she thinks to put me off with the Court-Custom; that's good, i' faith; and I must afford her my Ware for nothing: Where's the Heart set with Diamonds I mist this Morning?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: We have search'd high and low, but to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Then I suspect my Lady Sinker took it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Suspect! Why, she's famous for it all the Town over.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Nay, that may very well be: For, to my knowledge, greater Ladies have been taken in the manner: But she shan't carry it off so.
I did not expect your Ladyship this half hour: Betty, set on the Tea-Water.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: We had a mind to chat by our selves; prithee shut the Door, that we may be private.

div.stage: [Siam goes out, the Scene shuts upon her.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: I swear I'm in Mortal apprehensions: My Lord Lofty has my Secret, and I know him capable of any thing, to be reveng'd of me.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: What can he do? he's disgrac'd at Court: And if he rails now, no body will believe him.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Ay, but he knowsâ€”

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: What does he know? he knows you're a Woman.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Lord! you know where I have a Mulberry spotâ€”

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Is that all: he brib'd it from your Woman.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Well, I'll do what I can to prevent his being believ'd; carry it civilly to him, and speak better of him than ever.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: So will the Town believe you but an honest Jilt at worst.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: But this Sir Ruff is such a blustering half-witted Coxcomb!

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: If he had less wit, he were ne're the worse for us: But a thousand Pound, my Dear!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: My Mistress bid me tell your Ladyship, Mr. Gayman's within, and has made up the number of the Raffle.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: We're a little busie yet, but shall be glad of his Companyâ€”

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: She's not displeas'd at his being hereâ€”
This Gayman is not for our turn, Child; he's an Observer; besides, tho' he loves his Pleasure, he swears he won't pay for't, till past fortyâ€” Here's Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The Chair must waitâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Send away thy Chair, Child; thou shalt go home with us. We have Bassett this Evening.

sp.speaker: Betty to Maria.
sp.p: I'll but pay it off, and return in a Moment.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: That's a pretence: 'Twas Gayman sent for her. He has so great a Friendship for her, that, contrary to the principles of a well-bred Man, he has ventur'd to give her good advice, and, I believe, warn'd her of our Company.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: I tax't her of it,
But she deny'd it.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: She's discreet, and has but one Weakness, immoderate love of Playâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: And love of me: I can make her do any thingâ€”

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: But one, my Dear: She's Virtuous.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: For that I keep her Companyâ€”

sp.speaker: Wish
sp.p: And for her Money: For, to my knowledge, you have won above 600 l. of her at Comet.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Not so much at Comet; but more at all Games.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The Company is all within, my Lord, Mr. Gayman, and Sir Ruffâ€” they're but looking on some Stuffs; if you're at leisureâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: My Lord, shan't we have your Company?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Indeed, my Dear, I did [Lord, Gayman, Sir Ruff enter. but stay to chuse some white Peeling for a pair of Breechesâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Drawers, my Lord, you mean.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Jesu! no; you know, I never wear Linings.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Shall we Raffle?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: I must drink some Tea firstâ€”
Siam, is the Tea ready?

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: 'Tis just put inâ€” Good Lord! I wonder you'll go so, so like a Sloven: Here's a Periwigg well comb'd; and a Cravat sits finely, to appear in Ladies Company.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Very well, Mrs. Siam; but had not you Twins 6 Months after you were Marry'd? Tho?

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: No, Limberham; nor will you get half a one, in 6 Years after you are Marry'd.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: I wonder, Ladies, any body will buy of Mrs. Siam.
Mrs. Bantam's things are ten times better.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Ten times dearer, and ten times worse, I faith:
What! Lord Tattletale, you told her, I said, she was a Papist.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: And she said you were an Atheist, And believ'd in nothing but Scotch-Divinity.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.l: And what do you believe in?
Nothing but a Favourite, or Sir Faeminine,
That old Woman in Man's Cloathsâ€”

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: He swears you're a Bawd Mrs. Siam.â€”

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Not to him, nor his Neeces, in good faith.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Why, why, pray?

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Why, he has no use for one; and they need none:
Lord help your Head; come drink your Tea.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Already in Council!

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: What Madam Wishwell has told your Ladyship, you may depend upon:
I am a Man of Honour, and your humble Servant, Madam.
sp.stage: Sir Ruff with Wishwell and Lady Malepert.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: My Lady believes you, Sir Ruff: To Night at Twelve;
You know the Garden-Door.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: My happiness is so amazing!

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Contain your self: We are observ'd:
What! drinking Tea, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Yes, if Siam wou'd give me a little Sugar;
I love sweet things mightily.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Yes, too much for a Wit:
There; 'tis Syrrup for youâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Prithee, Siam, fill me some Tea.

div.stage: [Sir Ruff goes awkerdly to help my Lady, and spills my Lords Dish upon himâ€”

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O law! he has scauld me to Death.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Pough! 'twas almost cold:
And Tea, you know, never burns.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Jesu! and what a pickle am I in!

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Here's a do with a drop of Water!
Come, let me rub you down, Tom dingleâ€”

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ounds! what's this? Kissing your Cockrill before my face! by Pompey! who am I? I'll pepper you, you and your young Urchin too; I will by Pompey.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O Law! Captain, but hear Reason:
Now as I hope for marssy, there was no harm.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ounds! that's a good one:
No harm to kiss my Dolly?

sp.speaker: Ldy. Mal.
sp.p: Nay, take my word for't, Captain,
You need not fear when I am by.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, look you, you may be as little concern'd
For your Puppy, as you please, Madam:
But for my damn'dâ€”

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, Numpee, don't disturb the Company; they were going to Raffle.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, by Pompey, you were a Raffling:
I caught you at it, a Raffling for my Honour, with a Pox to you.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: No, faith, Captain, we shall Raffle for a better thing.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ounds! Sir, what's that you say?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why, I say, what we Raffle for, is of Threescore Pound value: Say nothing, and you go to twelve with me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Say'st thou so, Old Boy? 'Tis so like Speering's,
That for once I am contented.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Mal.
sp.p: Come then, shall we Raffle?

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Here's the Box, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Two Cinques, and a Quater!

div.stage: The Company about the Table, Maria throws.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: That's Fifteen.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Exactly, my Lord; Four and Ten.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O law! no; Fourteen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And Thirteen, is Seven and Twenty
And Eighteen.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: No, two Sixes, and an Ace.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Well, that's Fortyâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Confederacy! did not you observe
Wishwell turn over one of your Dice?
sp.stage: They throw round, all but my Lady, and Gayman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Twas by chance, playing with her Fan.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: You're sincere your self,
And believe every body so, but me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Dam these Diceâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Before the Ladies, Sir Ruff?

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: But I always lose, when I play fair.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Mal.
sp.p: Come, now for my Fortuneâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Madam, I have some Doctors in my Pocket,
If you please to use 'em.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Mal.
sp.p: What Doctors, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Why, don't you know the Doctors?
The Dice that only run the high Chances.
I'll put 'em into your Box, and no body the wiser.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Mal.
sp.p: You shou'd ha' don't without telling me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: So I can still, Madamâ€”
I stand cross-legg'd for you, Madamâ€”
Vigorously done, Madamâ€”

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have lost it.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I despair of winningâ€” 'tis yoursâ€”

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ounds! I go to twelve with youâ€”

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come, throw, Sirâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: 'Tis mine with much ado.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A hard World, Faith, and Troth;
But I brought luck along with me.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I remember you, Captain.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sir, Sir Symphony, and his Instruments, are at the Door, in half a dozen Coaches, and stay for you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Adso, where's my Gittern?

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Why, Numpee, you broke your Gittern, you know.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: My Gittern! mouldy Chops! where were you bred I trow? But my Neighbour Twingle the Barber has one, I'll borrow it so long from his Customers.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Did you hear of the foolish Accident befell Sir Symphony?

sp.speaker: Ldy. Mal.
sp.p: What was't, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.l: Why, Serenading, t'other Night,
His Gittar, and he, fell into a Cellar,
And like to break both their Necks.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Mal.
sp.p: What say you to a Pooile at Comet,
At my House?

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Sir Ruff, Will you make one?

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: I am always devoted.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Ladies, shan't I be troublesom?

sp.speaker: ish.
sp.p: The Devil take him.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Mal.
sp.p: We shall be glad of your Company.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Well, I'll go before in a Hackney,
And get things ready for you: I find,
I must shew you the wayâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Well said, my Lord, you in the Front appear: And I may help you to bring up the Rear.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Lord Malepert's Dining-Room. Lord Malepert, and Wishwell.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: WEll, how do you like Sir Ruff? he's a little mutinous at my wit sometimes; but he's good natur'd; and then has the Sense, and Courage of a Lion: But the Barronet's Worship may pass for a Squire at Comet tho'.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: One wou'd almost swear he loses on purpose, to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Why so one wou'd, I vow now, if one did not know the Company.
Well, I swear now, Mrs. Wishwell, you look so young,
You are not above five and Twenty, are you?

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Nay, if you're witty upon your Friends, I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Prithee now, I won't be witty agen these two hours.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: For once I'll take your word.
Well, my Lord, you're happy in a good Lady;
She's as discreet, as she's handsome.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: You know a well-bred Man must not think too well of his own Wife: But I vow now, before I was Marry'd, I thought her as handsome as an Angel.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: My Lord Lofty has not been here of late.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: He wou'd hardly bow to me at the Play, last Night;
But I thought he was out of humour for being turn'd out; and yet I vow I had no hand in't.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: For being turn'd out of this House I believe.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O law! why I carry'd it the civilest to him in the World.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: But he desir'd your Lady shou'd be civil to him.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: And so she was, I hope: Why, I have known her alone with him, in her Closet, when she was deny'd to every body else.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: While she thought him a Man of Honour,
For your sake she suffer'd him.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Have a care what you say,
I'm told, he's likely to be greater than ever.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: But must not with your Lady.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Ay, but he must tho: I han't got the Patent he promis'd me.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: And he is to give you a new Crest to your new Coronet?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: No, really, I like mine very well: The Golden-Calf has been the Crest of our Family, ever since the Conquest.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: The Horns will grow in time.
Dull Man!
He has made Love to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Jesu! that's pleasant! A Statesman make Love! why, he can no more deal with a Mistress, than with a House of Commons.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Come leave your fooling; and promise me, not to quarrel with him; you shall promise me, for you are so nice in points of Honour I know.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Honour! Lord help your Head (as Siam says) I have as much
Honour as I care for; I am a Lord;
And shall hardly quarrel to get more.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: But you must promise me then, to take no notice of it to my Lady: she'd never forgive what I tell you; out of the respect I have for you both.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Nay, I vow I'm mightily oblig'd to you; and so is my Wife; tho' the Jesters in the Dancing-Room are apt to laugh at me, when I tell 'em so. But had he the Impudence to make Love to her?

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Ay, more than so, he surpriz'd her one day, in her Closet, and wou'd ha' ravish'd her.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O law! I did not think a Man of Fifty cou'd ravishâ€”

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Had not her Virtue, and my seasonable assistance prevented him: But I found her just faln into a swoon.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: How! fal'n into a swoon! nay then he might ravish her:
But tho I say it, that shou'd not say it, there are some of our Family (tho' they can't ravish as well as he) shou'd they know this, were he ten times my Lord Loftyâ€” I'll do't my selfâ€”

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Nay, remember what you promis'd me.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: No matter for that, I'll about it instantly.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, you won't Murder him.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: No, that's the way to hang for't:
I'll complain to the Kingâ€”

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.l: And make your self and Family Ridiculous:
'Tis enough your Lady's Virtuous, and you know it.
But, what if this base Man shou'd brag of Favours?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Ay, but what signifies our Wives Virtue, if they are so lyable to fall into a swoon? Any Woman may be taken napping you know.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: But, if this base Man shou'd brag of Favours?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Why, let him brag; he's out of favour at Court; and whatever he says now goes for nothing in the Drawing Room; and I care not this what he can say any where else; for I wou'd not be known by my good will out of the Verge of White-Hall.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Or if some of your pretended Friends, shou'd go about to make you suspect me.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Tho' I shou'd surprize 'em in the manner, and you standing Centryâ€”

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: My Lady's hereâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: How! Wishwell! I protest I don't understand this:
Indeed my Lord I shall be jealouse of you.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: But shall I never be jealous of you, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: You need not, Dear, knowing your self so well:
If I were wantonly inclin'd, where cou'd I mend my self.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Where am I? sure Paradise is round me:
To touch thee's Heaven, but to enjoy thee! Oh!â€”

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Have my Lord and you been at the Cordial Waters?

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: We have been gravely talking of the deceit, and wickedness of the Age, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: I understand youâ€”
My Lord when shall we into the Country? I'm quite weary of this Town: The Company and publick diversions carry you so much abroad, I languish days without you: There I shou'd be oftener blest.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Well, Dear, I vow now, I won't be a moment from you, but when I'm in other Company: But that 'tis not the fashion to be fond of ones Wife, I verily believe I cou'd say a great many soft things to her.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Pray, my Dear, let's go to Monkey-Hill.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.l: O law! what shou'd I do in the Country?
There's no Levees, no Mall, no Plays, no Operas,
No Tea at Siam's no Hide-Park, no Musick-meetings,
No Basset, no Drawing-Room, no Masquerades,
Nor no Hackney-Coaches to run about in;
And you know I love running about mightily.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Nor, no body that understands good breeding.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: There the Justice's Lady comes to visit, and ask questions after the fashion: And how do they wear their Hair? Do they carry their Heads as high as they did last Easter Term?

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: And, Lord! is such a one as wicked as she was in the last Lampoon? We have no such Creatures in the Country, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: And then if I talk Wit, or banter Mr. Iustice about State Affairs, he stares at me, and does not understand me: Unless one laughs ones self, the jests are lost upon 'em.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Well, well, there are a Thousand innocent Diversionsâ€”

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: What! Angling for Gudgeons, Bowls, and Ninepins?

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: More wholesome, and diverting, than alway the duste Mill-Horse driving in Hide-Park.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O law! don't prophane Hide-Park: Is there any thing so pleasant as to go there alone, and find fault with the Company? Why there can't a Horse, or a Livery scape a Man, that has a mind to be witty: And then I sell bargains to the Orange-Women.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: If you lov'd, as I do, you wou'd like the Country; there I shou'd have you Weeks together; you might sit by, and see me work; or read a Play or a Novel to me.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Lord! you know, if I read three Minutes together,
I fall asleep: And then if I shou'd chance to be alone, what wou'd become of me? I never think, but it puts me into the Spleen, I'm ready to cry.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Now if you have over-acted your part, and he shou'd go into the Country.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: I know him too well for that.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Well, Madam, adieuâ€”

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Jesu! whither now?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: I'll be at home time enough to go to Bed with you:
But Sir Barnaby Banter, Captain Tilter, and Sir Cantaver Bawwaw stay in the side Box for me.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: I wonder you'll leave me for such Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O law! Coxcombs! have a care what you say:
Banter has a World of Wit: He drove my Chariot a whole Evening at Hide-Park, in my Coachman's Periwigg, and Livery: I swear he drives as well as any Gentleman in England: I wonder where he learnt it?

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: It may be natural to him; his Father kept a Coachman.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Then Sir Cantaver Bawwawâ€” I wish you had been with us t'other Nightâ€” we had a Country Cudden with us; he plaid upon him all Night; I warrant you, he dumfounded him a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Aye, and once, when I was bantering the Squire What do you think? He put some Gunpowder uner his Chair, and blew him up:

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: And did the Squire take it?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: At the first he was a little angry; But we all swore 'twas a Squibb thrown into the Window: Then Captain Tilter he came souse upon him indeed, and threw a whole Glass of Clarret in his face.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: And cou'd you swear off that too?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: No truly, the Put pluckt up a Spirit, struck Tilter, and Challeng'd him to go down with him; now the Captain beg'd his pardon, because he wou'd not spoil Company; but winkt, and laugh'd upon us all the while, for we were in the Secret you knowâ€” but I must go to 'em, or they'll laugh at me; and swear I'm under Correction; and that a Body wou'd not have every one know neither, you know.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: So, he's safe for this Night.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: How can we trust to that?

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Pray trust to me: I had him sent for; and will pretend to lie with you: Shou'd my Lord come home, we're gone to Bed; besides, you have bred him up to lie in his Dressing-Room, upon these occasions.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Well, if it must be so: For your sake I can do any thing.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: And something for your own: There's Money, that's certain: And for any other Disappointment, you may bear it the better from a Man you don't like: We must not always please our selves, Child.

div.head: SCENE the going into Sir Symphony's.
div.stage: Sir Ruff going hastily before Gayman.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Sir Ruff, Sir Ruff! you overlook your Friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: It must be a very good Friend, I don't over-look at this time.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Why, I'm an Emperour, and this the Night of my Coronation; Know, Friend, for thou art the only Confident of my Pleasures, that this Night, at Twelve, the Incomparable Madam Wishwell receives me at my Lady's Garden-Door: This being told, I must be gone: For nothing but the pleasure of imparting to my Bosom-Friend, cou'd detain me a Moment.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: But where's the haste now?

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: The haste! Why they may be at the Musick, for ought I know: And if I shou'd not be there to receive 'em: Where's the haste now?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Be Crown'd to Night, do you say? No, no, I'll spoil his Holiday.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.p: What, Gayman thoughtful?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I have it in my head, But you must help me out with it.

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.p: Mr. Grangerâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Well said, my Mercury!

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.p: Here's an Answer to your Letter, Sir,
But I must not be seen here, lest my Lady shou'd be known to be within in a Masque; and that she would not for any thing: She says, Sir, you must not know her.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: But what said my Lady Trickit?

sp.speaker: Iano.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I dare not stay any longer.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: There's thy Guiney, Child.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: A Lady's Trophy, Mr. Granger?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: A Fore-runner of dark Deeds; you shall hear it.

div.p: I'm glad you're Converted; and won't fail to be at Rosamond ' s Pond, at Ten exactly, where I will use my best Endeavours to Confirm you.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: A very Pious Gentlewoman, this!

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: She'd make an admirable Missionary For China, or the Mogul's Country.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Mine's a tender Conscience, and requires extraordinary, helps.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Methinks you're something frank of the Lady's Secrets.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: O Sir, they allow all Freedoms to us, who are able to discover their good Qualities, as well as their Intrigues.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: There's no Man hindred from telling, but he that enters no farther into the Secret.
Besides ours are Sworn Mistresses: And the more
We set out their Perfections, the more their Renown.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.l: Nay, mine's a very Sun-Flower:
When e're the Golden God but shows his Head,
She opens presently.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Fie, fie, I shall lose my Reputation with you.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: You! why with all your Prudence, of never bowing to your Mistress in a publick place, stealing glances under your Hat, and following her at a sly distance in the Mall, you are found out as well as we, who make no Mystery of the matter.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Nay, sooner; for your Gravity is suspected of a design, while the franker Fellows have not Credit enough with the Town to establish a Scandal.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: But a little Discretion does no harm.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Discretion! why that's enough to ruin a Man, with the whole Sex: He that has liv'd to twenty, without the Reputation of a wicked Fellow; will never be allow'd to be wicked in a fashionable Company as long as he lives.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: You're only for the Brutal part, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I don't know what you mean by the Brutal part:
Mine's a healthy Constitution; it ebbs, and flows, like the Sea, and needs nothing but it self; to cause its motion.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: There's part of Sir Symphony's
Eguipage, 'tis time to followâ€”

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: At Ten a Clock! I shall watch you, Mr. Granger.

div.stage: [Scene drawn, shews a Table, with Instruments, Chairs set, Sir Ruff, Gayman, Granger, Garnish, Women in Masks, Captain, Bullies, Sir Symphony tuning Instruments, Drydrub tuning his Cittern, knocking at the Door, the Porter busie in his Imployment.]

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Who's there? What wou'd you have?

sp.speaker: Without.
sp.p: Is Mr. Scrapewell within?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: No, you may find him at the Bear.

sp.speaker: Without.
sp.p: Tell Sir Symphony here are some Gentlemen desire the favour to come in.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, I can't let you in:
Here's scarce room already, for the Gentlemen
Performers, to stir their Elbowsâ€”
Well, what's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Without.
sp.p: Sir, here's Mr. Humdrum's Base-Violâ€”

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Give it me.

sp.speaker: Without.
sp.p: Here are Ladies.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: The Ladies must come in.

div.stage: Enter L. Susan, and Mrs. Judy, Masqu'd.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.l: O law! yonder he's talking to other Ladies.
But that's because I was not here:
Yet he is not to know I am here;
Tho' I hope my little Iano has told him.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.l: 'Tis soâ€”
Thus by the hobble in her Pace,
AEneas knew his Mother's Grace.
Now will I be a very Obedient Lover,
And not know her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ounds! this may be myâ€” No, no, it is not she.
sp.stage: The Captain peers about the Masks.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: Ladies, you're very welcome: Chairs there.
Wou'd you wou'd unmask, and joyn the Arms of your Beauty, to the force of the Musick, that not a Heart might scape.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: I know, Sir, you are too well bred,
Not to give us our liberty,

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: This Place is Sacred to the Fair,
You must Command, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Knight, is your Noctural here?
Are they good Goods, I must examine.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Jesu! this rude Fellow!

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p:
Sir, you may talk till the Musick plays,
But here you must excuse me,
I suffer no Ruffling.â€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Zounds! Sir, I'll excuse neither them, nor you,
For all your scraping.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: This must be improv'd to a Quarrel.
Hark you, Sir Ruffâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Zounds! Sir, I'll protect the Damsels, as much as any Man.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Ay, Sir Ruff, get the rude Fool beaten,
That wou'd affront 'em, do.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Jesu! Mr. Granger, protect me,
I'm ready to dye.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: There's no danger, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Pray lead me to a Chair, I tremble every joint of me;
I shall fall into a Fit.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: 'Twou'd break Sir Symphony's Heart, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Law! I hope you don't know me;
I protest I wou'd not be known for the World.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I only guess your Quality: by your air.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: But why do you tax me for Sir Symphony?
I swear, Sir, I value no body more than your self:
But, I vow, you have oblig'd me extreamlyâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: All Discords! Fourths, and Sevenths! Gentlemen.
Wou'd that Ear of your's were reform'd onceâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: In a Pillory?

sp.speaker: Sir. Sym.
sp.p: Come, come, let's Tune, we make the Ladies stay.

div.p: He takes a Base-Viol, and while he is Tuning, one of the Bullies unwinds the Pegs over his head: Then he lays down the Bow, which the Bully draws through the Candle; when Sir Symphony tries to play, he can't make it sound.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: Lord! Gentlemen, 'tis impossible to Play at this rate:
Standing so near me, as you do, your Breath has so moisten'd my Strings, they won't sound.

sp.speaker: 1 Bully.
sp.p: Dam me Tom, the Knight Crowds most splendidly: I'll banter him: Pray, Sir, when you lengthen a Crotchet into Quavers, and divide it by Minums, does not your Cravat-String deaden the sound of your Fiddle?

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: Mine's a Cremona, and cost me 50 Pounds, Gentlemen,
Pray suspend your Curiosity, and come to my Chamber,
And I'll resolve you any Question in Musick.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: But, Sir, if the volatile parts of Musick should justle with the effluviums of the Air;
For Tico Brache holds, all sounds go in a right line by undulation: Can common time be consistent with a Jigg?

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, you make such a noiseâ€” I make all my Jiggs in common time; are you satisfy'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: But if Harmony was first discover'd, by the beating of Hammers upon an Anvil; why shou'd not your Head make the most melodious, Instrument?
For Aristotle holds that your hollow Vesselsâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: If you're for a Cockpit, soâ€”
Come, pray let's beginâ€”

div.stage: [All the while the Symphony Plays, he beats time, and speaks in admiration of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.l: O Gad! there's a flat Note!
There's Art! How surprizingly the Key changes!
O law! there's a double relish! I swear, Sir, you have the sweetest little Finger in England! ha! that stroak's new; I tremble every inch of me:
Now Ladies look to your Heartsâ€”
Softly, Gentlemenâ€” remember the Ecchoâ€”
Captain, you play the wrong Tuneâ€” O law! my Teeth! my Teeth! for God's sake, Captain, mind your Citternâ€” Now the Fuga, bases! agen, agen! Lord! Mr. Humdrum, you come in three barrs too soon.
Come, now the Songâ€”

div.head: A SONG.
div.byline: Set by Mr. H. Purcell, and Sung by Mrs. Hodgson.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: THo' you make no return to my Passion,
Still I presume to Adore:
â€› Tu in Love but an odd Reputation,
Faintly repuls'd to give o're:
When you talk of your Duty,
I gaze on your Beauty,
Nor mind the dull Maxime at all;
Let it Reign in Cheapside,
With the Citizen's Bride,
It will ne'er be receiv'd in Whitehall.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: What Apocryphal Tales are you told?
By one, who wou'd make you believe.
That, because of to have, and to hold,
You still must be Pinn'd to his Sleeve:
'Tis apparent High Treason,
Against Love, and Reason,
Shou'd one such a Treasure engross,
He that knows not the Ioys,
That attend such a Choice,
Shou'd resign to another who does.

div.head: A SONG.
div.byline: Written by Anthony Henly Esquire, Set by Mr. Purcel, and Sung by Mrs. Ayliff, and Mrs. Hodgson.
div.l: NO, no, no, no, Resistance is but vain,
And only adds new weight to Cupid's Chain:
A Thousand Ways, a Thousand Arts,
The Tyrant knows to Captivate our Hearts:
Sometimes he Sighs imploys, and sometimes tries
The Vniversal Language of the Eyes:
The Fierce, with Fierceness he destroys:
The Weak with Tenderness decoys.
He kills the Strong with Ioy, the Weak with Pain:
No, no, no, no, Resistance is but vain.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: This is admirable: But if you wou'd oblige the Ladies, you must play your Solo.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: With all my Heart, if the Captain will accompany,

sp.speaker: 1 Bully.
sp.p: Pox a' this scraping, and tooting:
Shall we Ecclipse, Tom, and make it a Rankum?

sp.speaker: 2 Bully,
sp.p: No, no, we'll dumfound the Baronet.

div.stage: [They dumfound him, on each side, as he turns.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: Who's that? What do you mean?
This is not to be born:
Is't you, take that, Sir.

div.stage: Turning quick, one hits him in the Eyeâ€”
[Strikes him with a base Viol, and leaves it upon his Head.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: This is a common Cause.

div.p: They draw, drive the Bullies out, the Women run out at the other door, Sir Ruff retires to a Corner of the Stage, and draws, the others returnâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: These Brutes have almost destroy'd all the publick Diversions of the Town.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Stand you by Sir Symphony,
I'll bring him a Challengeâ€”
I've always thought you brave, Sir Ruff.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Why, who dares think otherwise?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I believe Sir Symphony will meet you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Or I'll post him: But what has he done?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Softlyâ€” You design'd it, I suppose; and your best way is to be before hand with him, I'll stand by youâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Why I saw him; he encourag'd 'em: Besides, Fidler's but a scurvy Title for a Knight?

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: Why did he call me Fidler?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: He said you were a wretched scraper,
Only fit to play to a Garland upon a May-Day:
My Lady Susan heard him, as well as I.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: Nay if one were sure of that, if she heard him:
One wou'd not do a foolish thing, hand over head, without Reason, you know.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: If you bring it to any thing, let me serve you?
You shall find me at my Lodgingsâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Well then, desire him to meet me, with his Sword in his Hand, to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: If he finds you so backward, he'll never ask your pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: But to Night I have Business, you know.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Greater than your Honour?

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: 'Tis very unfortunateâ€” But use your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Sir, I hope you'll pardon my Message.
Sir Ruff desires you wou'd meet him, with your Second, in Moorfields.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: I was just designing to send to him, to meet me, to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: He desires it may be to Night, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. Sym.
sp.p: To Night?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: At twelve: The Moon shines very clear:
At Bedlam Gate, at twelve, Sirâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: I must send to Mr. Granger: I shan't fail, Sir.â€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I have business for an Hour; but get you ready, you need not make your Will, I believe; I'll meet you at the Sun Tavern behind the Change, and not failâ€” to disappoint you of your Seconds.

div.head: SCENE III. Rosamond's Pond. Granger alone.
div.p: Let the Woman deserve as little as her Man, she seldom fails of a favourable opinion of her own Charms; and, in the Intrigue, if it be possible, will be the greater Fool of the two. Because I like Trickit, she thinks I'm in love with her: Why, how has she the impudence to think so! But she does think so; for in this Note, she has promis'd to meet me here: If she has Honesty enough to be as good as her Word; she needs no greater Curse: There was no occasion of my knowing that she can make her Husband a Cuckold, to make me have an ill opinion of her: I always thought so ill of her that 'tis now necessary to think a little while well, to think worse of her than I did: That must be my reason of liking her; a malicious Pleasure of revenging the Quarrel of those Fools (not forgetting her dear Lord) who have trusted, and been deceived by her, She can't deceive me.
Whom have we here? a Sister in Affliction!
If my Nymph, and her Shepherd have stray'd together: 'Twere a gentle Charity, of my side, to propose a Club of Inconstancy for a Revenge.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Mr. Granger! is't you?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: The best part of him, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O law! Mr. Granger! I fear I have tir'd your Patience: An impertinent Kinswoman popt in upon me, and kept me above half an hour, I vow now.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: A trick upon me! but I'll fit her.
I thought the Minutes Ages, till you came.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Jesu! and did you, dear Mr. Granger?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: By her, O Jesu, I guess the Partyâ€”
Madam, this Happiness attones for all.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Jesu! But can you love me dearly?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: More than Heaven.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: And you'll be constant?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: As Penelope.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: And you'll love me for ever and ever?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Amen, to the end of the Chapter.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: You'll swear all this?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: The Bible through, Madam: By your fair self, by allâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Hold, hold, good Sir, enough: Well, we shall be so happy; but when? for now you may command me.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Now, Madam, this instantâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Jesu! what do you mean:

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: To let you know how well I love you.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: No, I vow, I wou'd not for all the World: As I hope for Massy, you must hate me, to offer this.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Rather if I shou'd not offer it, Madam;
The opportunity, and you are kindâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O law! Sir! if you'll be honourableâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: There Shades are honourable: You are not the first Woman has trusted her Honour with 'em: Keep your own Counsel, and they'll tell no Tales to your Relations, to put you out of Countenance, as you walk bare-fac'd this way with 'em.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: But this to a Lady of my Quality.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Why, 'twere a downright flight upon you, not to offer to be civil to you: And a Woman of Quality can bear any thing better than a slight, you know: Besides, the Place, and Hour take all distinction off: Come, come, you have made as decent a resistance, as is necesary to excuse you to your Quality.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Granger, I thought'you had more respect for me, else I shou'd never have trusted my self with you, alone; in the Honourable way of Marriage, I own I cou'd receive you.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Why, you are marry'd already.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Crimine! No; who do you take me for?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Nay, if you're not marry'd, you must tell me.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Pray, who did you visit this Afternoon?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: A Worthy, Grave Lady, Lady Susan Malepert.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Suppose it her you talk to.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Suppose you her! suppose my Lady Susan with a Man, alone, at ten at Night, and in this place too! No, no, that is not to be suppos'd; and you are no better than you shou'd be, to offer it: If you were not in Petticoats, you shou'd know how I resent a wrong so great to her I so much honour.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Why then, I vow nowâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Nay, never load your Crime with Perjury.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Why, dear Sir, did not you appoint this place?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: But that Lady does not use to answer Appointments.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: And wou'd you make my generous Pity appear a Crime?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: For the generous Pity you speak of, I wou'd have you to know, that Lady has none for any Man, at Rosamond's Pond.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Jesu! Sir! Why sure 'tis no Crime, in an Honourable way, to see the Man one loves.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Love! why that's a Folly Lady Susan has renounc'd these twenty Years: Her Pulse beats even, and her sober Blood runs quiet in her Veins: And as for Matrimony, I know the very Name wou'd frighten her: Besides I dare not aim so high.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Jesu! Your Merit equals you to all things: And were I ten times what I amâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Thou art a thing I must despise; a Midnight Stroaler; nay worse, some mischief-making Fiend, who woud'st assume the Title of an Angel, to be the more a Devil. Bless me! methinks I see the cloven Foot peep under her Petticoat! Defend me! I say, and deliver me from such Company.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p:
Jesu! What can this mean? Either he did not, or he wou'd not know me: If he did not hope to meet me here, why did he write to me?
he had my Letter, else why came he hither? but then he said I was marry'd O law! may be he suspected Sir Symphony: Well, I must forbid him my Lodgings, I see that, to convince him. O law! but then he wou'd have been so rude! but that might be to try my Virtue; for I must needs say, he spoke all the while of me with the greatest respect in the World. Well, I love him, that's certain, and must not lose him; I'll be plain with him the first time I see him; for marry him I must, and wear my Wedding Ring upon my Thumb too, that I'm resolv'd on.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: This is some sort of Revenge upon the Rogue for refusing me his Money: How could he imagine I wou'd allow him a favour, when he had giv'n me such a reason to believe he did not think it worth paying for? I wou'd carry my malice farther, to punish his impudence in writing to me; but since his Note has contributed to the cheating him with the Person of Lady Susan; I am at the end of my design; and am contented only to laugh at himâ€”

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Rest you merry, Madam.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: They may laugh that win, they say, Mr. Garnish.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: And Ladies seldom lose in such a Town as this is, where there are so many civil Persons to play at your own Game too.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But how came you here at such a time?

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Madam, I can't be so indifferent a Lover, not to watch the Motions of your inclinations; finding your pleasure lie this Evening in the Park, I came to find it out.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Indeed if you had come a little sooner, you might have found it: I have been very well pleas'd since I came here.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: I believe so.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But you come a little too late to be a Witness of it; the business is over.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: O Madam, I wou'd not disturb you, if the business had not been over: I met Mr. Granger, Madam, and knew hy him the business was over.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And what said he to you? did not he look like an Ass?

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: As Men generally do upon such occasions: But I thought it unreasonable to tell him, he look'd like an Ass, because I knew he was not the first of your making.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Mr. Garnish!

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: I'm sure you have made an Ass of me: But my Jealousie has restor'd my Eyes; and now I plainly see you wou'd abuse me. When Granger sent you the Note of Assignation, I was with him

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, I received one from himâ€”

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: O! did you so?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: By Lady Susan's Page.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: By the same Token he gave the Boy a Guiney to encourage so hopeful a beginning; and told him, if he brought him an answer, he had another to set him up in his Trade: You were not wanting on your party, I know.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Why, truly, no; when I read it, I put it into another cover, and gave it the Page to carry his Lady: She was glad of the Appointment, I suppose, sent him an Answer, and came according to the Invitation.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: And what did you come for?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: To laugh at the mistakeâ€”

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: And set him right. O, very probable!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: 'Tis very true,

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: That you are very false.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I ne're was false to you.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: Away, away, it is not to be excus'd.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I don't excuse it.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: No, no, it never can.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Why then it never shall; and I am sorry I attempted it: If you don't think it worth your while to be satisfied, I'm sure I was in the wrong to endeavour it. Sir, as I remember, matters between you and me are entirely depending upon our good liking and pleasure: 'Tis not in the nature of an Amour to make one another uneasie: When once we begin to find faults, 'tis high time to find out fresh Friends, that have none: The severest Jealousie of this kind, lies within the Remedy of parting.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: It need not come to that neither, Madam.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir; I won't be suspected, I won't be enquired into: A Husband can do no more; and I have enough of one Husband and his ill humours at home, I thank you, ever to allow of a Husband abroad to torment me. Perhaps you think I can't break with you; I wou'd have you to know, Sir, I can, and will break with you and fifty more, rather than break one hours rest for any of you. I'll change as often as I shift my Cloaths, but I'll light upon a Man that has sense enough to value his own pleasure, without invading mine. If I depended upon you indeed, and there were no body else to be had, you might tye me to your own terms, but, make us thankful, there's roving room enough in this dear Town: I can provide my self, I warrant you.
A Mistress is a name implies Command:
Nor shall the Scepter fail within my Hand:
But if you wou'd take back that Pow'r you gave,
Marry the Woman you wou'd make a Slave.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.p: Lord Malepert' s House.

l.hi: O what a Night was that! how soft the Bed,
When on her panting Bosom I was laid!
Warm in Enjoyment, we together grew,

lg.l: And as one Mind, were but one Body tooâ€”

div.p:
How, how? one Mind! no, there I'm out: now can't I help thinking of Sir Ruff, and destroying the Memory of this Night's Pleasures, by calling to mind they were all design'd for another. Can't I be contented with the Enjoyment of a delicious Woman, without reflecting, that any body else might have had her as well as I. 'Tis an impertinent Curiosity in
our Natures, that when we have discovered as much as we can, to please us, will always drive us upon something to find fault with: Curiosity did I call it? Nay, Gad, there's ingratitude in the bottom on't, I believe; for 'tis the way of the World, in other favours too; to lessen those Obligations, as much as we can, which we han't in our honesty to return. Pox, I hate to be ungrateful: But I can't be ungrateful here, if I wou'd; for there was nothing design'd to me of the benefits I receiv'd: Wishwell let me in, at the hour appointed for Sir Ruff: The Lady receiv'd me for Sir Ruff; but when I think of the plesures that came after, that she shou'd still mistake me, for that bargaining Booby of her Bawds providing; I don't forgive her; The furious riot, the expense of Charms, the prodigality of Life, and Love (too vast for Nature's Bounty to support another hour) might have inform'd her better.
'Tis not yet Day: Wishwell's my Convoy; I can't get off without her:
No matter now, if she knows me.
Who's this follows me?

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: I have slept away my life,
My better part of it, my life of Love: He's gone from me:
Was this an hour of rest? Sleep had been welcome in a Husband's Bed; but in a Lover's Arms! he stole away, fearful of waking me, and fearful to be seen, he stole away,
In every thing, showing his care of me: How cou'd Sir Ruff do this? O Love! what can'st thou not do in a Woman's Heart!
That brutal thing, whom, as I thought, I loath'd,
Thy gentle Fires have softned by degrees, and melted into Gayman: Night be still my Friend, let me not see him, and I will think it was my Gayman still.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: O this Woman! I love her for her self, but hate her too.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Your Lover.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: O! be but ever so: Can you forget? Can you forgive me?
Can you excuse my being to be sold?
Let Wishwell bear the mercinary blameâ€”
Her baseness wrought me to her sordid ends:
But I'll return your Billsâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Return my Love: My Fortune is but yours.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: You are my better Fortune.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: O this happy Night. But to remember it,
A Locket, or your Pictureâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Take this Ring, to make a better Marriage.
Have you forgiv'n me?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: How shall I convince you?

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Why, only say you have.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Saying is too little: Doing's the living proof, that never lies; within you will believe meâ€”

div.stage: [Going out, Wishwell to 'em with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, where are you? Bless my Eyesight!

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Bless the Woman: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Are you the happy Man; Mr. Gayman?

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Gayman!

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Thank you for making me so, Mrs. Wishwell.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Gayman! then I am ruin'd:
Base Woman! have I deserv'd this from you?

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: No, but you deserve it from your self,
For putting this trick upon meâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: I put a trick upon you!

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: And you will find the benefit of it, in a little time; my Lord, and his drunken Companions, are coming up Stairs, to visit you: As you have manag'd the business without me; ev'n get off on't, as well as you can; I wash my hands of it, and will retire without being seen.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: O every way undone! follow her down the back Stairsâ€”

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Pox take her; she has double-lockt the Door.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: What shall I do! what will become of me!

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, let the worst come to the worst,
Sir Ruff is oblig'd to take care of youâ€”
But I'll bring you off this time, I warrant you.
sp.stage: Enter Lord Malepert, Granger, and 2 Bullies.

p.hi: And he that is giv'n to doat,

sp.p: On Woman's inconstancy:

p.hi: I wou'd not be in his Coat,
For a great deal of ready Mony.

sp.p: What! my Lady, and Gayman!
Are you too up together early, or late?
Here's my Lord and I are in Conjunction too:
Why faith, Madam, we thought of nothing, but the Spirit of Clery:
We did not expect such good Company, my Lordâ€”

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: No, really, I did not expect to find a Man with my Wife.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.p: But see how odly things will happen sometimes.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Ay, so they will, very odly indeed sometimes.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Odly, Mr. Granger!â€” What the Devil do you mean? [Aside.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I'll bring you off, I warrant you. Madam,
Gayman's an honest, well condition'd Fellow;
But somewhat sleepy towards Morning:
How did your Ladyship get him up so soon?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Prithee recollect thy self: All's ruin'd else.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I must go snacks, Gayman.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: He's must'ring all his little Malice, 'twill end in mischief certainly.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Nick, go you and fetch the Constable:
But before he comes, Madam, I command you,
In the King's Name, to tell me, what you two have been doing together, in my absence, against the peace of my Bed, and Bosome?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Doing, my Lord!
Why 'tis plain enough what we have been doing!
Any body may see what we have been doingâ€”

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Very plainly, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Or if they can't see; 'tis but hearing you talk, as you do; and they may easily find what you have been doing:
Did not we sup together?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: The Devil's always very powerful at this time of the Morning, Gentlemen; but bear Witness,
He says, they supt together!

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: They supt together! We, I say we; Granger, your Lordship and I, and these two honest Gentlemen. Gentlemen, I shall be proud to be better known to you:
sp.l: Pox, do you think I don't know what I say?
They remember me, tho' you won't, my Lord.

sp.speaker: 1 Bully.
sp.p: What! not remember Mr. Gayman!

sp.speaker: 2 Bully.
sp.p: O! perfectly, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why, my noble Lord, you are farther gone than I thought you were: If you drink your Friends down with your Bottle, I have done with you: Why, Gentlemen, I don't believe you drank very hard after I left you.

sp.speaker: 1 Bully.
sp.p: Not very hard, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Bully.
sp.p: Not above a Bottle a piece, after you left us.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Well, a clear Conscience is a great matter, I see.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: After he left us! Why, then I am drunk, and did not know it before: To my own thinking now I remember every thing in the Company as perfectyâ€”
Why how can a Man tell, at this rate, whether he's sober, or no?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Nay, I had been in the same pickle, if I had staid with you:
But when you saw I began to be maukish, you may remember, you sent me home before you, to knock up Mrs. Darkas, for the Cordial Waters; And you were to follow me.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, there you must excuse me; truth is truth; you did send him home, for how cou'd we else have found him here?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Why that's true: Why, well, if I have forgot it, I beg all your Pardons.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Is it not enough, my Lord, that you come home, at these unseasonable hours, but you must send up your drunken Companions before you?
Wishwell, and I were asleep, [Enter Wishwell.
When this unmannerly Royster came into the Dining-Room: We thought There had been Thieves, and poor Wishwell was almost frighted out of her Senses.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: I must close with her, for my own sake. Aside.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Was this well done, my Lord? Yet I won't think you cou'd be so ill a Man to design it, as a Plot upon my Honour, I won't think you cou'd.

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord is this the use you make of what I told you?
Do you deserve so good a Lady?
And Mr. Gayman, was it like your Character,
To be Confederate in so base an undertaking?
And all of you to make a Combinationâ€”

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Nay, Wishwell, as I hope to be sav'd now, 'twas altogether an Accident, no body had the least design upon my Wife, or her Honour, that I know of:
sp.l: There has happen'd some little mistakes, I must needs say;
But I am always so deaf with drinking, you knowâ€”
Gad so! here's Musick: See who 'tis that Serenades,
I love Serenading mightily.

div.stage: Enter Sir Ruff, and Sir Symphony with Musick.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.l: I have out-stay'd my Assignation;
But this Serenade will make her amends.
What's here? Gayman! Dammee, Sir, a man's well helpt up, that trusts to you for a second: I waited for you above two hours.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I was all that while serving you elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why do you think your self a fit Man for a Back-Door? You might as well have trusted 'em again to let you in at the Window: The Ladies design'd to laugh at you, and being your Friend, I made the quarrel, to send you out of their Power.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.l: Nay, Gad, I thought there was something in't:
For when Sir Symphony and I came face to face,
We were presently Friends, and agreed upon the Fiddles.
But since they design'd to make an Ass of me,
I'll have satisfaction, or my Money again.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Experience can never be bought too dear, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: Zounds, Sir, I'll go to her, and tell her she lies.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I'm glad I know your Principles.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Sir Symphony, why do you look so angry?

I hate Blood-shed; then Sir Ruff and you are Old Friends; besides, Gayman, and I had business, as you see, Sir; but how went the Tilt? Ha! I'm sorry, for both your sakes, I can see thro' neither of you:
I love a Visto, as my Lord says, mightily. [A Servant Enters.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: There are some Masquers-below,
Desire to be admitted.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: O Gemeni! Wife, let 'em come up:
sp.l: Hark, you, Gentlemen, Let's even make a Night on't:
I have some Masquing Habits within; Captain Tilter,
Sir Ruff, Sir Symphony, we'll all be in Disguise.
I love a disguise, when every body knows one, mightily.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.l: Hang your Masquerades, I begin to be tir'd of 'em:
'Tis losing ones labour always upon other Mens
Mistresses; when you have waited upon a Gentlewoman
Thro' the Ceremonies of the Night,
And think of going home with her,

div.p: Tho' you have cram'd her Pockets as full of Sweet-meats as they can hold: Her own Spark appears in the Morning; beats you, perhaps, for offering to lead her to her Coach, and forces you to walk home, ankle deep, in your Turkish Habit.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.l: O very Foolish! Leave Sir Symphony to his own face,
He'll make nothing of that, I dare say for him:
Come, Gentlemen, we shall be pure and merry,
When we don't know one another.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I'm as good as my word, you see, Madam,

I've brought you off: I have been oblig'd to you, and have return'd you your favour: But you must own Madam, mine carries something the better air along with it; because I generously design'd it for your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Mal.
sp.p: What shall I say? What can I say?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I won't upbraid you, Madam, you have done me the second good turn you had in your Power to bestow: And since 'twas impossible to have you to my self; it goes a great way in my Cure, to know that any Fool may engage you for the time;

div.stage: Enter L. Trickitt, L. Susan, Maria, and Garnish.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Mal.
sp.p: O very fortunate! And kind in you, and all the Good Company: How came I by this favour?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Why, truly, Madam, being up at Cards, at Lady Trickitts, over the way, we cou'd not resist the temptation of the Fiddles.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.l: But came in our Masks,
For fear we shou'd not be welcome.

sp.speaker: Ldy. Mal.
sp.p: So near a Relation can't doubt that, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.l: Ladies, I esteem my self very luckily here,
For the Entertainment of so much good Company:
I have some Gentlemen in my Consort,
Whom I can prevail upon, to treat you in their way, with a Song, or a Dance.

div.head: A SONG.
div.byline: Written by Mr. Congreve, Set by Mr. Purcell, and Sung by Mrs. Ayliff.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: TEll me no more I am deceiv'd,
That Cloe's False, and Common:
By Heaven, I all along believ'd,
She was a very Woman:
As such I' lik'd, as such caress'd,
She still was Constant, when possess'd,
She cou'd do more for no'Man.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: But oh! Her thoughts on others ran;
And that you think a hard thing:
Perhaps she fanci'd you the Man;
Why what care I one Farthing.
You think she's false, I'm sure she's Kind:
I'le take her Body, you her Mind;
Who has the better bargain?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Dear, Madam, I beg you a thousand Pardons,

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Jesu! For what, Mr. Granger?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Till you pull'd off your Masque, I took you for a Scandalous Creature, I met in St. Iame's-Park last Night; she was drest so like you.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: That Lady was no ill Friend of yours, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: You have no cause to speak well of her; for she wou'd ha' made me believe, you were as bad as her self.
Pox on her, how she haunts meâ€” [Goes from her.
sp.l: What has Lady Susan done, Sir Symphony,
You don't make your Court to her?

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: I find he does not think it for his Reputation to marry a Woman, that would meet him in private.
I'le mention it no farther.

sp.speaker: Sir. Symp.
sp.p: May I presume, Madam, that this opportunity may be more favourable to my hopes.â€”

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, I know nothing of an opportunity; pray be quiet, you wou'd not talk of an opportunity before People, wou'd you?
Why I never saw the like of you.â€” [Leaves him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: She always uses me ill before Company.

sp.speaker: L. Trick.
sp.p: Was it fine Walking last night, Mr. Granger?
Was there good Company at Rosamond's-Pond?

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I did not see your Ladyship there.

sp.speaker: L. Trick.
sp.p: Me! Fie, fie, a Married Woman there! Mr. Granger!

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: What you were more Houswifely employ'd? [Garnish hears what passes between Trickitt and Granger.

sp.speaker: L. Trick.
sp.p: More to my mind a great deal.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: In private, Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Trick.
sp.p: In Laughing at you. Lord! Mr. Granger, I thought you had been off the Vanity of thinking Women in love with you: 'Tis past time a day for you to send Love-Letters about the Neighbourhood, to corrupt the civil Families: How had you the Conscience to think a Woman would have any business with you, but to laugh at you? I vow I thought you had been wiser.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Faith I thought so my self, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: And why would you put your self into any Womans power to disappoint you? I thought the Young Fellows only, the Beaus of a Years standing in the side Box, could be disappointed; Who, by the extraordinary opinion of themselves, from their first Summons, imagine it impossible for any Woman to stay away from 'em.
But you are satisfied at last, I see.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Indeed I am, that I was always in the wrong, when I had the least good opinion of you. I was in hopes of having it in my power to use you, as you deserve (which you should have been sure of) but since you have gone before me in this, I promise you, you shall never get the better of me in any other business as long as l know you: And till you are Older, I can't like you worse than I do. [Going from her.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.l: You have convinc'd and oblig'd me;
And I thank you for the satisfaction.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.l: Pray thank me, when you're oblig'd, Mr. Garnish;
I have done nothing to convince you:
'Twas necessary to clear my self;
And I have done it, without a regard to your jealous thoughts upon the matter.

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: I promise you, I'le ne're be jealous more.

sp.speaker: L. Tric.
sp.p: Then here I promise you, I'le never give you cause to be jealous.

div.stage: Enter Ld. Malepert, Sir Ruff and Bullies, in Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: The Ladies shall know us, if they please.

sp.speaker: Sir Ruff.
sp.p: We're men for their turn; Sons of Darkness, And fit for the business of the Night.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.l: To beat up a Bawdy-house, you Scoundrels,
How came you here?
sp.stage: [They draw upon the Masqueraders, and drive 'em off, and return.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.l: Why don't you know us?
You're the strangest People in the World! Murder a Man in his own House!

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: I'm for defending the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: How could'st thou be so barbarous to the Cuckold of thy bosom, to frighten him so terribly?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: He began to be troublesome:
Besides I have at present a Quarrel to the Family.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.l: I hope you are not hurt, Mr. Granger,
I wou'd not for the World, I Vow now,
Have such a thing happen in my Company:
What will the World say?

div.stage: Goes to Wishwell and Lady Malepert.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.l: Why e'en nothing at all:
The world does not care if we were Hang'd,
I assure you.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: This Ring, Madam, I Valu'd only as an Evidence of my good fortune, which, since the case is so plain, I return to your Ladyship again.

I don't observe that dearness between you, and Mrs. Wishwell, that us'd to be; don't let me make a breach in that Friendship, which may be so serviceable to you both: You're both in a mistake, neither has betray'd tother: Indeed Sir Ruff made me his Confident, and qualifi'd me for the welcome I have found. Mrs. Wishwell, now I'm sure you'll be my Friend, since you know I have it in my Power to be your Enemy.
And for you, Madam, I am oblig'd to justifie you to every body, but my self.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.l: 'Tis more than I deserve. O, I must hate you,
You have undone me with the only Man
I ever Lov'd or shallâ€”

sp.speaker: Wish.
sp.p: Then I am sure to keep her in my own Power.

div.stage: Enter Ld. Mal. in his own Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Lord! this is the oddest thing in the World,
Turn a Man out of his own Doors, for coming to divert you: 'Twas as much as I cou'd do, I Vow now, to perswade the Foot-Man to let me in again.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why, were you one of 'em, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: One of 'em, yes I think I was.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Who wou'd ha' thought you kept such Company?

sp.speaker: Garn.
sp.p: We did not know you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Sir Ruff, I assure you, takes it bloody ill of you; if it had not been in my house,
He Swears, he would have mauld some of you.
I don't know but he may send you a Challenge.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: I hope not so, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Nay, I'll make it up, if I can.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: My Lord, you come very seasonably for the clearing of some difficulties, that have happ'ned to night, in Relation to your Lady.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Lord! what does he mean?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I wou'd vindicate her Virtue, as much as I can, from any unreasonable suspicions, you may have of it, upon my account; and therefore declare, in the prefence of all this good Company, that I have no design upon any body in't, but this Lady: And here I offer to Marry her. [To Maria.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Nay then he does revenge himself indeedâ€” Aside.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: What say you, Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Why, nothing, nothing in the World: Poor Rogue!
Silence gives consent, all the Town over.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Madam, your Ladyships interest would go a great way in perswadeing her. [To L. Mal.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Nay, my Wife will be for it I'm sure.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: Mr. Gayman, you may be sure of meâ€”
sp.l: To perswade her against it if I cou'd.
Wou'd I might never see his Face again.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Well, we shall live so pure and merry at one anothers Houses: Wou'd you were all Married, Gentlemen; there's no making a Friend throughly Welcome, I can tell you, without having a Wife of ones own to receive him.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Law! Mr. Granger, what if you, and I, should make it the Double Marriage? [To Granger who leaves her.

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: 'Tis an Old Play, Madam, and will never take.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: The Devil take him, I don't know what to make of him.

div.stage: [She applies her self to Sir Symphony.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: I know your thoughts, Maria.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Come, Madam, give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you may repent this rashness. [Gives her Hand.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: I may repent of some things that are past:
But I can never do any thing with you, to repent of.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: How the Tyrant Triumphs! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: You see, Madam, how happy you might make your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: O Law! Sir! You don't think so.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Hey day! Here's my Aunt upon the prick of Preferment too: Sir Symphony, and she are agreeing to go to Bed together.

sp.speaker: L. Su.
sp.p: Well if it must be soâ€” [Gives Sir Sym. her hand.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Uncle Symphony, with you joy of my Aunt Susan.

sp.speaker: Sir Sym.
sp.p: You do me the greatest Honour
In the World, Madam. [Siam Enters.

sp.speaker: Ld. Mal.
sp.p: Gad so! Here's Siam too, the more the merrier, we shall want Company to dance at all these Weddings: You shall be my partner, Siam.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Wou'd I were unmarried, upon the Condition
I never danc't at a Wedding again.

sp.speaker: L. Mal.
sp.p: What's the matter now, Siam?

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: Why the Captain has been drunkning with my Lord all night, and coming home in one of his damn'd old Humours, has beaten me black and blue, and turn'd me out of Doors. [Capt. Enters.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: How's this, Captain?

sp.speaker: L. Tric. and all.
sp.p: We'll pull the old Rogue to pieces; beat his Wife!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why Dolly, Dolly, you shou'd bear with the failings of your Lord and Masterâ€”

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: I do bear with your failings, you know I do,
You old fumbling Fool you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And not betray the secrets of my Dukedom, the Mysteries of our Bed, and Board, Dolley.

sp.speaker: Siam.
sp.p: I'le be plagu'd with you no longer: I'le give you a separate Maintenance, and be rid of you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I'le come in for my thirds, Dolly, that you know the Law will allow me: But let's see your
sp.l: Separate Maintenance: I Marry'd you only to maintain me;
Who marries an Old Woman for any thing else?
And if I can make you Maintain me, d'ye see,
I don't much care whether I'm Marry'd to you, or no:
But I know your Grievance; you wou'd have me
Begin to propagate, like a Patriarch, at threescore,
And try to do good in my generation: But who
The Devil can doo good upon you? You are
Past it as well as I; and so faith let's have a
Dance, and agree upon parting in the morning.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Well, Granger, you are still to continue a Batchelour, it seems

sp.speaker: Grang.
sp.p: Why faith, Sir, 'tis as much as a Man can do, to secure a Reputation, in his own keeping; he need not venture it in a Womans:
sp.l: Especially when she Stakes so little against it:
For in Miscarriages of Marriage,
We favour still the weaker Sexes faults:
So when the Wife's abus'd, and Husband horn'd
The Woman's pity'd, but the Cuckold Scorn'd.

div.head: EPILOGUE,
div.l: SEE the Effects of a poor Maids Last Pray'r,
Driv'n by meer want of Husband to despair.
And Ladies, in a Barren Age as this is,
'Tis hard for all of us to have our Wishes.
She, for a time pretended to a Wit;
And yet you see her Project wou'd not hit:
Let her Example teach you; there's no urging
These Sparks, to take an Antiquated Virgin
They fear the growing Cares of Marry'd Lives,
And ventureâ€” only on their Neighbours Wives.
Be Wise in time, set not too great a value
On your fine selves, and still stand, shall I, shall I.
For while the Dreams of Coach and Six deceive you,
The honest Squire, despis'd, may chance to leave you:
And when poor Maids are driven to Petition,
We seldom find they better their Condition
Yet thus with some of you it daily happens,
You lose the Beast, in hopes to get the Trappings.
You scorn to stoop below a Top Gallant:
And all pretend to Ride the Elephant:
As if you had forgot the thing you want.
Tho' each lost hour you pass a Fiery Tryal,
And ne'er refuse without a self-denial.
Led by the Custom of the Sex, you strive
To blind the World, while you your selves deceive:
You may pretend a nice indifference;
But Truth must still be Truth, while Sense, is Sense:
Disguise your Inclinations as you can:
Yet every Woman's Business is a Man.
